    Notwithstanding other provisions of this chapter to the contrary, signs meeting the definition of temporary sign may be permitted and maintained subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  Temporary signs may be erected for up to 60 continuous display days per calendar year. This may be broken into separate permit periods as short as three consecutive display days. A permit is required for each separate period a temporary sign is displayed. 
(2)  Temporary signs shall be either ground signs or wall signs and shall be governed by the general regulations for those types of signs except as contained herein. 
(3)  A temporary sign shall: 
a.  Not exceed 32 square feet in sign area counting all sides of multi-sided signs. 
b.  Not exceed ten feet in height above the mean ground level for ground-mounted signs or above the lowest mounting point for non-round-mounted signs. 
c.  Be limited to one sign per address occupied by the permittee at one time. 
d.  Not be issued a permit for display for a period of less than three consecutive days. 
e.  Be issued a permit for display a maximum total time period of 60 days per year per address occupied by the permittee. This may be one or more separate permits. 
f.  Not be displayed in excess of two signs in quantity at one time at any multi-occupant building or premises. 
g.  Be displayed only at the location indicated on the permit. 
h.  Not be placed within the public right-of-way or on public property. 
i.  Be firmly and securely attached to the ground or a building. 
j.  Not be displayed on or attached to any accessory structure, fence, equipment, trailer, vehicle, or plant life. 
k.  Be removed promptly upon the expiration of the permit period. 
l.  Be a conventional flat sign, a suspended or affixed flexible banner, an A-frame sign, a fan-inflated dancing balloon or a ground-mounted flexible device intended to move with the assistance of the wind and shall be made of fire resistant materials and securely attached to a building or the ground. 
m.  Not include pennants, pinwheels, motorized or flashing lights or devices, personnel or any device held, displayed or manipulated by personnel nor any items or media otherwise prohibited or limited by ordinance. 
n.  Be maintained in a condition as originally manufactured and erected without tears, holes, fading or other deterioration. 
o.  Include oversized inflatable devices in excess of 32 square feet in area and/or ten feet in height subject to the general regulations for temporary signs except such oversized inflatables may only be given permits for a maximum of 30 days per year (each day for an oversized inflatable shall be charged as two days toward the 60-day annual allotment of display time for a temporary sign). Oversized inflatables shall be securely attached to the ground or a building. No such device shall be located to obscure visibility or the line of sight for motor vehicles in public rights-of-way or on private property. 
(4)  Temporary sign fees and compliance deposits: 
a.  The fee for temporary signs shall be $2.00 per square foot with a minimum sign permit fee of $25.00. The fee for oversized inflatable devices shall be $6.00 per day with a minimum fee of $18.00. No refunds of the permit fee or adjustment to the display days attributed to a temporary sign shall be made after a permit has been issued and the sign erected. 
b.  A temporary sign compliance deposit of $100.00 shall be paid with every temporary sign permit. Such compliance deposit shall be refunded in full to the permittee upon the temporary sign remaining in compliance with all Ballwin regulations throughout the entire time of its display and it being removed in accordance with the permit time frame. Failure to maintain the temporary sign in compliance with Ballwin regulations and remove it in accordance with the permit shall result in a forfeiture of the full compliance deposit amount. 
(Code 1973, § 21-52; Ord. No. 2212, §§ 3-6, 10-14-91; Ord. No. 03-11, § 3, 2-10-03; Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 22-61. - Wall signs. 
    Wall signs are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Except as provided in this section, no wall sign or signs shall be allowed to exceed 100 square feet for any single building, store or occupied unit. 
(2)  Any commercial building or occupied unit shall be permitted a wall sign having an area equal to ten percent of the area of the front wall of the building or portion of the building occupied. 
(3)  A sign not to exceed 300 square feet may be placed on a building the front wall of which is not less than 300 feet to the right-of-way line of a public street or to the limits of any other street or roadway. 
(4)  Any building occupied by a single tenant and having a front wall area of over 2,000 square feet adjoining a public street may have a wall sign with a sign area not in excess of ten percent of the area of the front wall of such building; provided, however, that the area of a wall sign shall not exceed 300 square feet. 
(5)  A building on a corner lot may have signs on each street side of such building, and the area of each wall adjoining a public street shall be computed separately to determine the size of the sign which may be erected on each wall. 
(6)  All wall signs shall be made of noncombustible materials. Moldings and cappings may be made of wood. 
(7)  All wall signs shall be safely and securely attached to a building. 
(8)  No wall sign shall project beyond or above the face of the surface to which it is attached. 
(9)  No wall sign shall be erected so as to cover the doors or windows of any building, or otherwise prevent free ingress and egress to or from any window, door or fire escape of any building. 
(10)  No wall sign shall extend more than 12 inches from the surface to which it is attached. 
(11)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, these restrictions shall not apply to a sign erected on a water tank by a water service utility, regulated by the Missouri Public Service Commission when, such a sign is displayed for identification purposes. 
(Code 1973, § 21-53; Ord. No. 13-34, § 1, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 22-62. - Automobile dealership or mall signs. 
    Automobile dealer and automobile mall signs are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  No sign may exceed 500 square feet of total sign area per product line. 
(2)  Total sign area may not exceed 1,500 square feet. 
(3)  Only one post or ground sign per product line is allowed at each automobile mall. 
(4)  No post or ground signs may exceed 300 square feet. 
(5)  Ground signs shall comply with section 22-52 except for the requirements of subsection 22-52(6), (7) or (8). 
(6)  Wall signs shall comply with section 22-61, except that wall signs of 200 square feet are allowed on walls of less than 2,000 square feet. 
(7)  All freestanding signs must have a minimum of 75 feet between signs and must not be located within any street right-of-way lines. 
(8)  No sign shall be located to obscure visibility or the line of sight for motor vehicles at intersecting streets, alleys, driveways or at curb cuts. 
(9)  Post signs shall have a maximum height of 25 feet above the established street grade; and the post or support columns must be a minimum of six feet: 
a.  Away from any adjacent street right-of-way line. 
b.  Away from any structures. 
(Code 1973, § 21-54) 
Sec. 22-63. - Maximum total sign area. 
    The maximum total sign area that may be exhibited or maintained by, for or on behalf of any one person or business establishment occupying any tract of land or premises shall be 200 square feet except as set out in sections 22-51, 22-61 and 22-63. 
(Code 1973, § 21-55) 
Sec. 22-64. - Billboard signs. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  Billboard signs shall conform to the general provisions of ground signs except as provided herein. 
(2)  Billboard signs shall conform to the provisions of State of Missouri Statutes regulating billboards. 
(3)  Billboards and billboard sign structures shall be free-standing and may not be attached to or supported by any other building or structure, nor may such sign or structure project over or above any other structure of any kind intended for permanent or temporary human occupancy. 
(4)  Billboard signs and billboard sign support structures shall only be allowed in the C-1 zoning district. 
(5)  The area of billboard signs shall be counted toward the maximum allowable sign area as established in section 22-63. 
(b)  Lighting. All billboard signs shall be lighted according to the following: 
(1)  Only be illuminated externally. 
(2)  Be illuminated in such a manner that the lamps, lenses and other light generating, directing and/or focusing devices cannot be observed directly from any point on the ground or from any point within a structure on adjoining or surrounding properties or rights-of-way. 
(3)  Not be illuminated in a manner that generates in excess of ten foot-candles of illumination or adds additional illumination to the existing ambient light levels such that the foot-candles exceed ten when measured upon adjoining rights-of-way or properties at the closest proximity to the sign. Billboard erectors shall provide a sealed report from a Missouri licensed engineer familiar with such matters as to the amount of increase in foot-candles that will be generated at such locations. Such report shall be provided prior to the issuance of any permit for a billboard or billboard support structure. 
(4)  Have no revolving, rotating, flashing, oscillating, intermittent or moving lights other than public service information such as date, time, and temperature. This shall not include electronic changing message boards. 
(5)  Shall only utilize illumination that shines in a generally upward direction away from the ground and surrounding rights-of-way, structures and properties but in accordance with the other provisions of this section. 
(c)  Size. All billboard signs shall meet the following size requirements: 
(1)  The maximum total area for a billboard sign, including all faces, is 200 square feet. This shall include borders, trim, frames, etc., but shall not include supporting structure elements. 
(2)  The maximum height of a billboard sign or billboard sign structure shall not exceed 20 feet. 
(3)  The maximum area limitations shall apply to the combined area of all display faces of a billboard sign. A billboard sign structure may have no more than two displays per facing. Multiple faces shall only be erected in back-to-back or V-type configurations. A multi-faced billboard sign structure shall be considered one sign. 
(d)  Height. All billboard sign structures shall meet the following height requirements: 
(1)  Have a maximum height of 20 feet above the average ground level as measured under the sign. Under no circumstances shall the highest point of the sign or supporting structure be more than 20 feet above the average ground level below the sign. 
(2)  Have a minimum of 14 feet of clearance between the bottom of any overhanging or projecting portion of the sign or support structure and the ground, pavement or other surface beneath where vehicular traffic may occur. 
(3)  Have a minimum of ten feet of clearance between the bottom of any overhanging or projecting portion of the sign or support structure and the ground, pavement, or other surface beneath where pedestrian traffic may occur. 
(e)  Spacing. All billboard signs and billboard sign support structures shall be subject to the following spacing requirements. All distances relative to spacing shall be measured from the closest parts of the signs or supporting structures. 
(1)  Shall be spaced a minimum of 1,320 feet from all other billboard signs. 
(2)  Shall be spaced a minimum of 500 feet from any post or free-standing directory sign. 
(3)  Shall be spaced a minimum of 250 feet from any existing ground sign. 
(4)  Shall be spaced a minimum of 100 feet from any other free standing existing outdoor advertisement. 
(5)  Shall be spaced a minimum of ten feet distant for every one foot of height of the sign and/or supporting structure from the boundaries of all residential zoning districts. 
(6)  Shall be spaced a minimum of ten (10) feet from any public or private right-of-way. 
(7)  Shall be spaced in such a manner that the fall zone will not overlap or intrude into a public or private right-of-way, any structure intended for occupancy by people or chattels, or any parcel other than that upon which the sign is erected. 
(8)  Shall be spaced no more than 660 feet from Manchester Road. 
(Ord. No. 99-26, § 2, 5-24-99) 
Sec. 22-65. - Signs excluded from regulation. 
    Except for the provisions of section 22-21 et seq. hereinabove, the following signs are excluded from regulation under this chapter: 
Integral decorative or architectural features of building or works of art, so long as such features or works do not contain letters, numbers, trademarks, moving parts or lights. 
The fees required under section 22-24 herein shall be waived for public and private elementary, middle and high schools. 
(Ord. No. 05-07, § 1, 1-24-05) 
Secs. 22-66-22-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OUTDOOR ADVERTISERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-81-22-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-101. - Advertising sign business license required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of billposting or outdoor advertising by erecting or maintaining any of the signs defined in this chapter within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a license from the city to conduct such business. 
(Code 1973, § 21-62) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, ch. 14. 
Sec. 22-102. - Application. 
    Applications for a license required by this article shall be made on forms furnished for such purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 21-63) 
Sec. 22-103. - Licenses not transferable. 
    No license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be transferable. 
(Code 1973, § 21-64) 
Sec. 22-104. - Expiration. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this article shall expire on June 30 following the date of issuance. 
(Code 1973, § 21-65) 
Sec. 22-105. - Renewal. 
    All licenses required by section 22-101 shall be renewed according to the provisions of the licensing ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 21-66) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, ch. 14. 
Sec. 22-106. - Revocation. 
    The city may revoke any license issued pursuant to this article upon satisfactory evidence that the licensee has violated any provision of this chapter. A license so revoked shall not be reinstated within 30 days of its revocation and then only on satisfactory evidence that the cause for revocation has been removed. 
(Code 1973, § 21-67) 
Chapter 23 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-1.5 et seq.; administration, ch. 2; health and sanitation, ch. 12; refuse, garbage and rubbish storage in housing, § 13-78; abandoned vehicles, § 15-411 et seq.; littering, § 17-60; sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 21; weeds and vegetation, ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Refuse disposal in cities, RSMo 71.680 et seq.; solid waste disposal, RSMo 260.200 et seq.; municipal solid waste management plans, RSMo 260.220; hazardous waste management, RSMo 260.350 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Accumulation prohibited. 
(a)  The accumulation of garbage or refuse of any type for a period in excess of five days is hereby declared a public nuisance and a clear danger to public health. No owner, lessee or occupant, nor any agent, servant, representative or employee thereof, of any lot, ground or premises, or any part thereof, shall allow or maintain any such accumulation of garbage or refuse upon any lot, ground or premises in the city or upon streets or upon the right-of-way adjoining such premises or upon any adjoining sidewalk. 
(b)  This section shall not prohibit the accumulation or storage of refuse produced as an incident to the lawful use of the same premises where stored; provided such stored refuse is pending removal or disposal and does not remain on the premises for a period in excess of seven consecutive days, and provided further that the refuse is placed or stored in a container or is otherwise screened from the view of persons upon adjacent property or rights-of-way, except on a day scheduled for collection when it may be placed adjacent to the public right-of-way. 
(Code 1973, § 10-2) 
Sec. 23-2. - Scattering. 
    No person within the city shall cast, place, throw, deposit or sweep any refuse or garbage upon any street or public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1973, § 10-3) 
Sec. 23-3. - Compost. 
    No provision of this chapter shall be interpreted to prevent the accumulation of compost for residential use, provided that it is contained in an appropriate container, does not create an odor detectable on neighboring properties, and does not harbor or induce the accumulation of vermin. 
Sec. 23-4. - Storage of infectious, hazardous and special wastes. 
(a)  No person possessing or generating infectious, hazardous or special waste shall permit such infectious, hazardous or special waste to be placed in storage containers ordinarily used for waste that is not infectious, hazardous or special waste, as the case may be. 
(b)  No person possessing or generating infectious, hazardous or special waste shall place such waste in storage containers which are not clearly marked "Infectious Waste," "Hazardous Waste," or "Special Waste," as the case may be. 
(Code 1973, § 10-6) 
Secs. 23-5-23-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTORS 

Sec. 23-21. - Licenses required. 
    No person shall collect or remove from any premises within the city, or convey over any of the streets or alleys of the city, any garbage or refuse unless such person shall have a license to do so as may be required under the provisions of this chapter or any other regulation or ordinance of the city, for each vehicle utilized for such purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 10-18) 
Sec. 23-22. - Collection to be by city or authorized trash hauler only; exception. 
(a)  All garbage or refuse accumulated in the city on premises occupied by a dwelling shall be collected, removed, conveyed and disposed of only by the city or a trash hauler or a trash hauler's employee and it shall be unlawful for any person other than an employee of the city, a trash hauler or a trash hauler's employee to use any street or public way within the city for the collection, removal or conveyance of any garbage or refuse from dwellings within the city. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the actual producers of refuse, or the owners of premises upon which refuse has accumulated, from personally collecting, conveying and disposing of such refuse; nor shall anything in this section prohibit collectors of refuse from places outside of the city from hauling such refuse over city streets, provided such collectors comply with the provisions of this chapter and with any other governing law or ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 10-19) 
Sec. 23-23. - Authority to enter into agreement for collection of refuse. 
(a)  The mayor shall have the authority to enter into an agreement on behalf of the city with any person approved by the board of aldermen for the collection, removal and disposal of garbage and refuse from premises occupied by dwellings; provided, however, that such trash haulers shall not exceed two in number at any one time. 
(b)  All agreements executed under the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to contain the requirements and conditions as herein set out, regardless of whether the same are set forth in such agreement or regardless of any terms or provisions of such agreement to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(Code 1973, § 10-20) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to contract for collection and removal of refuse, RSMo 71.680. 
Sec. 23-24. - Prerequisites to agreements. 
    Before there shall be executed on behalf of the city any agreement with any person for the collection, conveyance and disposal of any refuse accumulated within the city on premises occupied by dwellings, the person so contracting with the city shall at his own expense furnish: 
(1)  A certificate of workers' compensation insurance. 
(2)  A certificate of general liability insurance providing for coverage in the amount of $1,000,000.00 for personal injury and property damage and naming the city, its elected officials and employees as additional insured. The policy shall provide that it cannot be cancelled or terminated except upon at least 30 days' written notice to the city. 
(3)  A bond in favor of the city and all persons who shall furnish labor or materials in connection with such contract, in such amount and with such surety as the board of aldermen may approve, conditioned upon the faithful performance of all obligations of such person under the contract, for the payment of all bills for labor or material furnished in connection with such contract, for compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances, and for the indemnification of the city from any and all loss, costs or expense which the city may incur by reason of injury to persons or property as a result of any negligence or alleged negligence of such person in doing work under the contract. 
(Code 1973, § 10-21; Ord. No. 2164, § 1, 5-13-91) 
State Law reference- The Workers' Compensation Law, RSMo 287.010 et seq. 
Sec. 23-25. - Revocation of agreement. 
    The board of aldermen may revoke the city's agreement with any trash hauler upon a finding by the board of aldermen that a trash hauler has not complied with any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 10-22) 
Sec. 23-26. - Payment of trash haulers. 
    The board of aldermen, in its sole discretion, may provide for the payment to a trash hauler out of the general revenue fund of the city or out of the proceeds of any fee which may be established and assessed, by ordinance or resolution of the board, against the occupants or owners of dwellings within the city for the collection, removal and disposal of garbage or refuse. A trash hauler is hereby authorized to collect on behalf of the city any such fees which may be assessed. The fees which are collected by a trash hauler shall be retained by him as and for full payment for his services in collecting, removing and disposing of garbage and refuse; and such fees which are so collected shall be in full settlement of the city's obligation to a trash hauler. However, the city shall not be responsible for any fees which a trash hauler may be unable to collect. 
(Code 1973, § 10-23) 
Sec. 23-27. - Trash hauler not required to collect from persons delinquent in payments. 
    When any owner or occupant of a dwelling shall be 30 days delinquent in the payment of fees established and assessed for the collection of garbage and refuse, a trash hauler shall not be obligated to collect, remove or dispose of any garbage or refuse from the premises of any persons so delinquent. 
(Code 1973, § 10-24) 
Sec. 23-28. - Subcontracting prohibited without prior approval. 
    No trash hauler shall, without first receiving the approval of the board of aldermen in writing, sublet or subcontract any portion of the work to be done in collecting, removing or disposing of garbage or refuse. 
(Code 1973, § 10-25) 
Sec. 23-29. - Vehicle requirements. 
    No license shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter for any vehicle utilized by any person for the collection, removal, disposal or hauling of garbage or refuse within the city unless: 
(1)  The vehicle to be so utilized is equipped with a metal body of leakproof construction and a metal cover constructed in such a way that both the body and cover of the unit shall be leakproof. 
(2)  Such vehicle is equipped with a fire extinguisher of a type approved by the National Fire Protection Association for highway transport use. 
(3)  The owner or operator of such vehicle has deposited with the city clerk evidence that he has secured, paid for and has in effect a policy of motor vehicle liability insurance in the minimum amount of $1,000,000.00 for personal injury and property damage and naming the city, its elected officials and employees as additional insured. The policy shall provide that it cannot be cancelled or terminated except upon at least 30 days' written notice to the city. 
(4)  Such vehicle has been inspected by a member of the police department and found to be in good condition with all safety appliances operative. 
(Code 1973, § 10-26; Ord. No. 2165, § 1, 5-13-91) 
Secs. 23-30-23-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PRECOLLECTION, COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 23-46. - Authority to refuse to collect garbage or refuse. 
    The collection and removal services may be refused for failure to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 10-38) 
Sec. 23-47. - Accumulation of refuse prohibited. 
(a)  No owner, lessee or occupant, nor agent, servant, representative or employee of any such owner, lessee or occupant of any lot, ground or premises, or any part thereof, shall keep or allow to be kept upon any such lot, ground or premises any refuse unless it is in containers meeting the requirements of this article. 
(b)  The fact that refuse has accumulated or is kept on premises or property in violation of the provisions of this section shall be prima facie evidence that the occupant and owner of the premises or property are responsible for the violation occurring. 
(Code 1973, § 10-39) 
Sec. 23-48. - Containers to be provided. 
    Containers shall be provided by the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of the premises. 
(Code 1973, § 10-40) 
Sec. 23-49. - Container requirements generally. 
    Containers shall be watertight and have tightfitting lids used in place at all times. 
(Code 1973, § 10-41) 
Sec. 23-50. - Containers to be kept in sanitary manner. 
    All containers shall be maintained and kept in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. 
(Code 1973, § 10-42) 
Sec. 23-51. - Capacity and maximum weight of containers. 
    Containers placed for collection by the city or a trash hauler shall not have a capacity of more than 31 gallons nor exceed 75 pounds in weight, when filled, unless authorized and allowed by the city or the trash hauler. 
(Code 1973, § 10-43) 
Sec. 23-52. - Replacement of nonconforming or damaged containers. 
    Any container that does not conform to the provisions of this article, or may have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof, shall be promptly replaced upon notice. 
(Code 1973, § 10-44) 
Sec. 23-53. - Number of containers restricted. 
    Containers shall be limited in number according to the provisions of the contract in effect with a trash hauler. 
(Code 1973, § 10-45) 
Sec. 23-54. - Refuse containers in front yards prohibited. 
    No person shall place or keep or permit the placing or keeping of a refuse container in the front yard (as that term is now or may in the future be defined in section 1-2 for the city's zoning ordinance) of premises or property owned, occupied or controlled by him, except when such containers are screened from view within a sight proof enclosure erected in compliance with the applicable provisions of this Code or are placed for collection not more than 12 hours prior to the day of collection nor more than 12 hours after the time of collection. 
(Code 1973, § 10-46) 
Sec. 23-55. - Precollection practices. 
(a)  Liquids. All garbage and refuse shall be drained of any liquid before being deposited for collection. 
(b)  Boxes and cartons. All boxes and cartons shall be collapsed before being placed for collection. 
(Code 1973, § 10-47) 
Sec. 23-56. - Frequency of collection. 
    Trash haulers shall collect and remove garbage and refuse accumulated upon premises occupied by dwellings at least one time each week. 
(Code 1973, § 10-49) 
Sec. 23-57. - Hours of collection. 
    No trash or refuse hauler shall collect, remove or convey garbage or refuse in the city between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, nor at any time on Sundays. Vehicle operators and the collection companies for which they work, either as employees or as contractors, shall be jointly and severably responsible for a violation of this section and may be penalized in accordance with the provisions of section 1-6 of the Ballwin Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1973, § 10-50; Ord. No. 2505, § 1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 23-58. - Points of collection. 
    Refuse containers shall be placed at ground level on the property, accessible to and not more than five feet from the side of the street or alley from which collection is made; provided that containers may be placed for collection at other than ground level at a distance of more than five feet when an additional fee for the payment of the extra service is agreed upon by the trash hauler and the occupant or owner. 
(Code 1973, § 10-51) 
Sec. 23-59. - Manner of operating collecting vehicles generally. 
    All vehicles used for the collection, removal, disposal or conveyance of garbage and refuse shall be operated so as to prevent garbage and refuse from being blown, dropped or spilled. 
(Code 1973, § 10-52) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 15. 
Sec. 23-60. - Refuse to be disposed of outside city. 
    Persons collecting refuse within the city shall dispose of the same outside the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 10-53) 
Sec. 23-61. - Enforcement procedures. 
(a)  Citation of a violation of the provisions of this chapter 23 shall be made according to the following procedure: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Contain a statement of the reason for the citation. 
(3)  Allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act required under the citation, not to exceed ten days. 
(4)  Contain an outline of remedial action which if taken will effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  Be served on the owner, an agent thereof or the occupant, as the case may require. 
(b)  Service of a citation under this section shall be deemed to be properly served upon the owner, an agent thereof or the occupant if a copy thereof is: 
(1)  Served on such person personally; 
(2)  Sent by certified mail to the last know address of such person; or 
(3)  Posted in a conspicuous place in or about the property affected by the citation. 
(c)  If an owner fails to comply with the requirements of the citation, the city may seek remedy using one or more of the following: 
(1)  Issue a municipal court summons and the owner shall be subject to fine in accordance with section 1-6 of this Code. 
(2)  If the owner of the property fails to remedy the citation within the time period specified, the city may rectify the violation, and the cost of compliance shall be certified to the finance officer who shall cause the certified cost to be included in a special tax bill. If the certified cost is not paid within 30 days, the tax bill shall be considered delinquent, and the laws governing delinquent and back taxes shall govern the collection of the delinquent bill. The tax bill from the date of its issuance shall be deemed a personal debt against the owner and shall also be a lien on the property until paid. 
(Ord. No. 05-05, § 2, 1-10-05) 
Sec. 23-62. - Roll-off trash containers in residential districts. 
    Portable temporary roll-off trash containers or dumpsters are permitted in residential zoning districts under the provisions of this section. Not more than one such container shall be allowed per residential lot. Containers shall not have a capacity greater then 20 cubic yards. In no instance shall the container be placed in the public right of way or easements. The use of such containers shall not exceed 30 days, unless due cause for an extension of time can be demonstrated. For good cause shown, one 30-day extension may be granted. One roll-off trash container may be allowed in conjunction with building or demolition permit during the valid time of such permit. 
(Ord. No. 05-09, § 2, 2-28-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-09, § 2, adopted Feb. 28, 2005, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 23-61. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, the provisions have been redesignated as § 23-62, at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 24 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Requirements for acceptance of street. 
(a)  No road, street or thoroughfare within the city shall be accepted by the board of aldermen as a public street unless the street is constructed according to the plans and specifications of the city. 
(b)  The plans and specifications mentioned in subsection (a) shall include plans and specifications for type of construction and surfacing and also for width. 
(Code 1973, § 22-1; Ord. No. 2474, § 2, 10-9-95) 
Sec. 24-2. - Authority to close streets temporarily. 
(a)  The city engineer or chief of police is authorized to close any highway, road or street in the city and withdraw the same from the public use temporarily and during such period as public work thereon or other public emergency or expediency shall make such action necessary. 
(b)  No person shall use or attempt to use any highway, road or street so withdrawn from public use or drive or attempt to drive any vehicle thereon during the period the highway, road or street is withdrawn from public use. 
(c)  The city engineer shall place a sign at each end of the portion of such highway, road or street withdrawn from public use. Such sign shall meet the standards of the current edition of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices For Streets and Highways, published by the U.S. Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration. 
(Code 1973, § 22-2) 
Sec. 24-3. - Obstructions in streets and street rights-of-way. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall obstruct in any manner whatsoever the free passage or use of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, or erect, construct, place or maintain any speed bumps, horses, ridges, depressions, fences, gates, pipes, chains, bars, basketball hoops, hockey nets, skate ramps or any other type of structure or obstruction in, on, or across the paved portion of any public street or roadway within the city. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation shall erect, construct, place or maintain anything within the unpaved portion of any right-of-way owned by the city except as follows: 
(1)  Grass and/or landscaping materials, including trees and bushes, provided that such landscaping materials do not hinder sight distance, become a public nuisance or otherwise obstruct or interfere with the free and safe movement of traffic. 
(2)  Mailboxes as authorized or required by postal authorities. 
(3)  Traffic control devices and signs installed and maintained by the city or other governmental entity. 
(4)  Public utility lines and equipment including, but not limited to, street lights, cable television installations and utility poles, provided that appropriate permits are obtained from the city. 
(5)  Private driveways and sidewalks, provided that appropriate permits are obtained from the city. This authorization shall not be construed to allow for installation of parking pads adjacent to or parallel with the roadway. 
(6)  Directional or informational signs as may be approved by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(7)  Lawn sprinkler systems, invisible fences or similar subsurface installations may be installed or maintained on the public right-of-way exclusively at the risk of the person, firm or corporation installing or maintaining the same. In the event that such systems are installed or maintained in the public right-of-way, the city shall have no responsibility or liability whatsoever for removal of or damage to such systems as a result of the use, maintenance or repair of any street, sidewalk, or right-of-way by the city or its agents, employees or representatives, nor shall the city be responsible or liable for any damage done to any such item caused by or resulting from the use of the public right-of-way by members of the public. 
(Code 1973, § 22-3; Ord. No. 2684, § 1, 6-8-98) 
State Law reference- Encroachments and obstructions, RSMo 79.410. 
Sec. 24-4. - Street and sidewalk construction generally. 
(a)  Generally. All streets and sidewalks constructed within the city shall conform to the standards of St. Louis County except (i) Meramec River gravel shall be used in lieu of crushed limestone where concrete is required for construction; and (ii) in situations where a cul-de-sac is constructed, the diameter of the landscaped island shall be 20 feet. 
(b)  Streets. Streets shall be constructed in accordance with section 25-91. 
(c)  Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be four inches thick, (six inches thick at residential driveway and seven inches thick at all others), four feet wide and shall have expansion joints at intervals of no greater than 20 feet and crack control joints at four-foot intervals. 
(d)  Curbs; ramps in sidewalks at crosswalks. All new curbs which are constructed within the city, and all existing curbs which are a part of any reconstruction, shall comply with this subsection. In order to enable persons using wheelchairs to travel freely and without assistance, at each crosswalk a ramp shall be built into the curb so that the sidewalk and street blend at a common level. Such ramp shall be not less than 36 inches wide and shall not have a slope greater than one inch rise per 12 inches length (8.3 percent). In all ramps there shall be gradual rounding at the bottom of the slope. Deviations from the standards set forth in this subsection shall only be permitted where conformance to such standards is impractical or physically impossible and where methods, material and dimension used in lieu thereof do not create a hazard. Such deviations must first be submitted to the city engineer for approval or rejection based on sound engineering principles. 
(e)  Vault under sidewalks. No vaults shall be constructed under sidewalks within the city unless a building permit is obtained to construct vaults under sidewalks subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The area which may be occupied under a sidewalk by a property owner in front of a building shall not be allowed in the space between the front lot line and a line five feet back of and parallel to such line or the space between the curbline of the street and a line five feet back of and parallel to such line, whichever allows the most setback from the street. 
(2)  In no instance shall an excavation be made in any street, alley or driveway for the construction of a vault. 
(3)  In no instance shall a vault be constructed that does not provide for the removal or drainage of water, snow or ice from such vault. 
(4)  The vault shall be constructed of reinforced concrete and have a proper foundation, the design of which must be approved by the city engineer. 
(5)  The vault shall be covered with a grate or door capable of supporting 3,000 pounds. 
(f)  Maintenance and repair of sidewalk, private driveway, alley, driveway culverts, etc. The owner of property abutting any sidewalk along any avenue, street, road or highway within the city is responsible for that sidewalk's maintenance: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  The owner of any property having a private driveway, alley, avenue, road, street or highway connecting to any public right-of-way used for alleys, avenues, roads, streets or highways within the city shall maintain and repair any defective portion, including the drainage culvert beneath the private driveway, alley, etc., that is located within the public right-of-way in conformance to the standards as required by the city on file in the office of the city engineer. All such private driveways, alleys, avenues, roads, streets or highways shall blend at a common level with any adjoining sidewalks and any alleys, avenues, roads, streets or highways located on a public right-of-way. 
(3)  New driveways constructed or repaved by the City of Ballwin within the public right-of-way shall be limited to the cost of either traditional poured concrete or hot mix asphalt confirming to the standard driveway details and specifications of St. Louis County Department of Highways and Traffic. The concrete shall be air-entrained poured in place six inches thick with Meramec River gravel used in lieu of crushed limestone. No colored, exposed aggregate, stamped, textured concrete or other special surface treatments shall be permitted. Asphalt shall be three-inch thick St. Louis County hot mix Type "C" surface course mix on six-inch Type 1 Aggregate Base Course. 
(4)  That portion of driveways within the public right-of-way between the street and sidewalk shall be the responsibility of the adjoining property owner. Where no sidewalk exists, that portion of the driveway within the right-of-way shall be the responsibility of the adjoining property owner. 
(5)  Sidewalks within the public right-of-way, except those extending private walkways to the street, shall be the responsibility of the City of Ballwin. Portions of the sidewalk through driveways and alleys shall be constructed in accordance with sections 24-4(a) and 24-4(c) and with joints separating this portion of the sidewalk from the driveway shall be installed providing the same width as the adjoining sidewalks. 
(g)  Location of private driveway, alley, avenue, road, etc. No private driveway, alley, avenue, road, street or highway shall enter any public right-of-way within 75 feet of any public right-of-way lines of the intersecting streets in the districts zoned PA public activity district, C-1 commercial, C-2 regional shopping, C-3 planned limited commercial, S-1 service, and MXD mixed use development unless the lot is less than 100 feet; then it shall not be located closer than two-thirds of the length of the lot from the public right-of-way lines of the intersecting streets. 
(h)  Condemnation; repair, removal and replacement. The board of aldermen may by ordinance condemn defective driveways that have not been repaired or removed and provide for the construction of new driveways in place of driveways so condemned or removed. The city maintains sidewalks within public right-of-way or easement except those which serve private property. 
(i)  County-owned properties. All real estate owned by the county and situated within the city shall be subject to the provisions of all ordinances of the city related to the erection and maintenance of sidewalks, guttering, curbing, and fences along streets and alleys, and the paving of streets to the same extent as that of private citizens of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 22-4; Ord. No. 2584, § 1, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 03-26, § 1, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 08-40, § 1, 12-8-08; Ord. No. 11-12, § 1, 3-14-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 71.365, 71.367; condemnation of sidewalks by fourth class cities, RSMo 88.713; county property subject to ordinances of fourth class cities, RSMo 88.743. 
Sec. 24-5. - Sidewalk master plan. 
    The map designated sidewalk master plan on file with the city engineer is adopted as the master plan for installation of sidewalks by the city; and sidewalks will be installed in accordance with such plan upon receipt and approval by the board of aldermen of petitions signed by 75 percent of property owners adjacent to the street or 75 percent of the property owners of a subdivision served by such street. 
(Ord. No. 2150, § 1(22-6), 2-11-91) 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, ch. 25. 
Sec. 24-6. - Illustrations. 
    The following are illustrations of the construction of different types of streets: 

EXHIBIT 1 



(Ord. No. 2375, §§ I, II, 4-11-94; Ord. No. 2584, § 2, 3-24-97) 
Sec. 24-7. - Requirements for acceptance of private roadways. 
(a)  Under no circumstances will the city accept any private parking lot for public maintenance. The determination as to whether a facility is a parking lot under the provisions of this section is solely that of the board of aldermen. 
(b)  Roadways with groups of parking spaces directly adjacent to the roadway pavement and within the proposed right-of-way, or adjacent to the right-of-way, but accessed by a curb cut within the right-of-way which approximates the overall length of the parking space group, may be considered for public maintenance if the total length of curb line (pavement edge) occupied by such parking or curb cut is less than 25 percent of the total length of the curb line (pavement edge) being considered for acceptance and public maintenance. 
(c)  Any private roadway accepted for public maintenance must be accepted for its entire length within the city limits of Ballwin. 
(d)  A petition from owners of property representing 75 percent of the front footage of land along both sides of a private roadway must be presented and verified before the board of aldermen may consider the acceptance of a private roadway for public maintenance. 
(e)  One hundred percent of the property owners upon whose property a publicly maintained roadway will be established must agree to the roadway dedication by signing a plat or other similar document. No compensation shall be paid by Ballwin to any party for land or expenses associated with such dedication. The cost of preparing and recording a dedication plat or similar instrument shall be the sole responsibility of the petitioner. 
(f)  The city will not pursue condemnation or other legal action against any property owner(s) who refuse to dedicate property or sign a petition. 
(g)  All roadways accepted for public maintenance must be within a recorded right-of-way dedicated to Ballwin. A right-of-way accepted for public maintenance shall generally be no less than 50 feet wide. 
(h)  If a dedication plat must be prepared for recording, it is the responsibility of the petitioner(s) to provide and record the document. 
(i)  The board of aldermen shall not approve or execute any dedication plat which creates lots or setbacks which are nonconforming under the provisions of Ballwin's Zoning Ordinance. The board may consider approving a dedication plat involving existing nonconformancies if the dedication plat does not increase such nonconformancies. 
(j)  No roadway will be accepted for public maintenance which cannot be accessed directly from another publicly maintained roadway within the Ballwin corporate limits. 
(k)  Roadways must meet the following physical construction criteria: 
(1)  The roadway must be paved with either concrete, asphalt or equivalent paving material acceptable to the board of aldermen. 
(2)  Pavement shall meet Ballwin standards for new roadway of the same kind. 
(l)  All pavement shall be in good condition and free of significant cracks, sinking, scaling, rutting or other deterioration. 
(m)  No right-of-way will be accepted for public maintenance which contains structures other than pavement, stormwater inlets, manholes, pipes and other customary roadway related improvements unless such structures are specifically identified in the dedication plat as being the perpetual maintenance responsibility of an adjoining property owner, trustee association or other entity acceptable to the board. 
(n)  Streets accepted for public maintenance must have appropriately designed, maintained and functioning curbs and gutters, roadside ditches, driveway culverts etc. which direct runoff into natural drainage ways without causing flooding, erosion, siltation or other problems to adjoining public and private property. 
(o)  Integral storm sewer systems must be in good condition. All pipes, culverts, inlets, manholes, etc. must be clear of blockages and functioning as designed. 
(p)  All storm sewer systems must be certified by a civil engineer, acceptable to the city, that they meet the minimum design and function criteria of MSD. The cost of such certification is the responsibility of the petitioner. 
(q)  Additional easements, outside of the dedicated right-of-way, may be required if it is determined that such easements are needed to properly maintain storm sewers, inlets, manholes, culverts, box culverts, roadways, shoulders, ditches and other such facilities within the dedicated right-of-way. 
(r)  All utility easements within the right-of-way proposed for public maintenance must be identified on the dedication plat. 
(s)  The city shall not expend public funds to bring any roadway, easement or right-of-way into compliance with these minimum guidelines in order to make it eligible for maintenance as a public facility. 
(t)  The board of aldermen, by ordinance, may amend, make additions to, delete or otherwise revise subsections (a) through (s) or this section by majority vote without respect to the passage of any period of time between such amendments, additions, deletions or other revisions if it determines that to do so is in the best long term and/or overall interests of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2474, § 2, 10-9-95) 
Sec. 24-8. - Manchester road sidewalk payment. 
    Property owners of property abutting Manchester Road having sidewalks constructed where none previously existed under the Federal Transportation Enhancement Program shall be responsible for 30 percent of the actual cost associated with sidewalk construction along their property abutting Manchester Road. Payment of such cost shall be due upon the transfer of any special use exception associated with the property. The city administrator is hereby authorized to develop a special use exception transfer fee which incorporates the cost of sidewalk construction associated with such property, which shall be due at the time of application for special use exception transfer. 
(Ord. No. 05-39, § 1, 9-12-05) 
Sec. 24-9. - Driveways and driveway aprons. 
(1)  The driveway apron is the portion of the driveway between the sidewalk and curb. Since this section of driveway only serves the adjoining property, the property owner shall be responsible for maintenance. This includes possible damage caused by salt. 
(2)  The City of Ballwin will replace the portion of driveway which serves as part of the existing sidewalk, considering that portion as sidewalk, serving pedestrians. 
(3)  For driveways where the gutter is integral with the driveway apron, the City of Ballwin will replace the apron only if the gutter requires replacement; however, a joint will be inserted, separating the gutter and the apron. This joint will allow for future gutter replacement without replacing the apron. 
(4)  If the apron and gutter are integral, but only the apron needs replacement, then the property owner is responsible for replacing both the gutter and apron. Again, a separation joint shall be installed. 
(5)  Driveway aprons shall be replaced with either concrete or asphalt. The driveway apron shall be concrete along streets with vertical curbs. 
(Ord. No. 11-49, § 1, 10-10-11) 
Sec. 24-10. - Roadway acceptance. 
(1)  Under no circumstances will the City of Ballwin accept any parking lot for public maintenance. For the purposes of this document, a parking lot is defined as a paved, graveled or otherwise designated area intended for the parking and/or storage of motor vehicles and trailers. Parking lots are not located within public rights-of-way, generally have no discernable physical separation between the area intended for parking spaces and the adjoining area intended for vehicular access to the parking spaces except painted lines or raised islands, and are intended for the parking and storage of vehicles and trailers. Such facilities do not function as a conduit (roadway) for vehicular traffic which is not intending to utilize the parking spaces within the facility or in adjoining parking facilities. The determination as to whether a facility is a parking lot under the provisions of this policy and definitions in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Ballwin, is solely that of the board of aldermen. 
(2)  Roadways with groups of parking spaces directly adjacent to the roadway pavement and within the proposed right-of-way, or adjacent to the right-of-way, but accessed by a curb cut within the right-of-way which approximates the overall length of the parking space group, shall not be considered for public maintenance. 
(3)  Any roadway accepted for public maintenance must be accepted for its entire length within the city limits of Ballwin. 
(4)  A petition from owners of property representing 75 percent of the front footage of land along both sides of a private roadway must be presented and verified before the board will consider the acceptance of a private roadway for public maintenance. 
(5)  One hundred percent of the property owners upon whose property a publicly maintained roadway will be established must agree to the roadway dedication by signing a plat or other similar document. No compensation shall be paid by Ballwin to any party for land or expenses associated with such dedication. The cost of preparing and recording a dedication plat or similar instrument shall be the sole responsibility of the petitioner. 
(6)  The City of Ballwin will not pursue condemnation or other legal action against any property owner(s) who refuse to dedicate property or sign a petition. 
(7)  All roadways accepted for public maintenance must be within a recorded right-of-way dedicated to Ballwin. A right-of-way accepted for public maintenance shall generally be no less than 50 feet wide. 
(8)  If a dedication plat must be prepared for recording, it is the responsibility of the petitioner(s) to provide and record the document. 
(9)  The board of aldermen generally will not approve or execute any dedication plat which creates lots or setbacks which are nonconforming under the provisions of Ballwin's Zoning Ordinance. The board may consider approving a dedication plat involving existing nonconformances if the dedication plat does not increase such nonconformances. 
(10)  No roadway will be accepted for public maintenance which cannot be accessed directly from another publicly maintained roadway within the Ballwin corporate limits. 
(11)  Roadways must meet the following physical construction criteria: 
(a)  The roadway must be paved with either concrete, asphalt, or equivalent paving material acceptable to the board of aldermen. 
(b)  Pavement shall meet Ballwin standards for new roadways of the same kind. 
(12)  All pavements shall be in good condition and free of significant cracks, sinking, scaling, rutting, or other deterioration. 
(13)  No structures, other than pavement and sidewalks, will be maintained by the city, unless such structures are specifically identified in the dedication plat as being the perpetual maintenance responsibility of the city. 
(14)  Streets accepted for public maintenance must have appropriately designed, maintained and functioning curbs and gutters, roadside ditches, driveway culverts, etc., which direct runoff into natural drainage ways without causing flooding, erosion, siltation or other problems to adjoining public and private property. 
(15)  Integral storm sewer systems must be in good condition. All pipes, culverts, inlets, manholes, etc. must be clear of blockages and functioning as designed. The Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District must agree to accept all of the storm sewer system. 
(16)  Additional easements, outside of the dedicated right-of-way, may be required if it is determined that such easements are needed to properly maintain storm sewers, inlets, manholes, culverts, box culverts, roadways, shoulders, and other such facilities within the dedicated right-of-way. 
(17)  All utility easements within the right-of-way proposed for public maintenance must be identified on the dedication plat. 
(18)  Ballwin will not expend city funds to bring any roadway, easement, or right-of-way into compliance with these minimum guidelines in order to make it eligible for maintenance as a public facility. 
(19)  The Ballwin Board of Aldermen reserves the right to waive any of the guidelines enumerated in this policy if it is determined that to do so is in the best long term and/or overall interests of the City of Ballwin. 
(Ord. No. 11-49, § 2, 10-10-11) 
Sec. 24-11. - Sidewalks. 
    The board of aldermen reserves the right to authorize installation of sidewalks within the public right-of-way whenever deemed to be in the best interest of the community. The board shall consider unique factors such as proximity to schools, parks, and public facilities, increased pedestrian activity and/or overriding safety concerns. Where appropriate, consideration should be given to connection with the existing sidewalk system. Approval requires a simple majority affirmative vote of the board of aldermen. 
(1)  Any new site development, whether residential or commercial, shall install sidewalks on both sides of the street. If the board of aldermen agrees that a new sidewalk is not appropriate due to future street improvements or tree preservation, they will require payment from the developer to the City of Ballwin an amount equal to the present cost to Ballwin for sidewalk construction. 
(2)  Ballwin will install sidewalks along one side of a public roadway under the city's jurisdiction, if a petition signed by at least 75 percent of the abutting property owners is received. Sidewalk construction will be budgeted on a first-come first-served basis as soon as is financially possible, but no sooner than the fiscal year following the receipt of the petition. Large petitions may be broken into multiple parts and funded over several years. Petitions received late in the fiscal year may be received too late to be included in the subsequent year's budget. 
(3)  Any petition signed by at least 75 percent of the property owners and accepted by the board of aldermen will be in effect for a period of two years from the date of acceptance. No petition in opposition to the accepted petition will be considered during this two-year period. 
(4)  Property owners along any a street that do not want a sidewalk must submit a petition signed by at least 75 percent of the property owners adjacent to the street indicating that they do not want a sidewalk. This petition would then be submitted to the board of aldermen for acceptance, provided a petition for sidewalks has not been received within the past two years. Once the petition is accepted, it remains effective as described in subsection (2) above. 
(Ord. No. 11-49, § 3, 10-10-11) 
Sec. 24-12. - Kehrs Mill Road sidewalk payment. 
    Property owners of property abutting Kehrs Mill Road having sidewalks constructed where none previously existed under the Federal Surface Transportation Program shall be responsible for 20 percent of the actual cost associated with sidewalk construction along their property abutting Kehrs Mill Road. Payment of such cost shall be due upon the approval of any redevelopment or subdivision associated with the property. The city administrator is hereby authorized to develop a fee which incorporates the cost of sidewalk construction associated with such property, which shall be due at the time of approval of such redevelopment or subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 11-50, § 1, 10-24-11) 
Secs. 24-13-24-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate excavations, RSMo 79.410. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-21. - Barricades required. 
    Every person who shall cause to be made any excavation in or adjoining any public street, alley, public place, highway, walkway, right-of-way or easement or who shall occupy any portion of any public street, alley, public place, highway, walkway, right-of-way or easement with building material or with any other obstruction shall provide, erect and maintain at all times along the line of work all such barricades, signs, lights and warning signals as may be necessary in the judgment of the city engineer to protect the public from the hazards arising from the operation. The city engineer may require additional protection of excavation. 
(Code 1973, § 22-21) 
Sec. 24-22. - Routing of traffic. 
    The permittee shall take appropriate measures to assure that during the performance of the excavation work, traffic conditions as nearly normal as practicable shall be maintained at all times so as to cause as little inconvenience as possible to the occupants of the abutting property and to the general public, provided that the city engineer may permit the closing of streets to all traffic for a period of time prescribed by him if in his opinion such closure is necessary. The permittee shall route and control traffic, including its own vehicles, as directed by the city police department. The following steps shall be taken before any street may be closed or restricted to traffic. 
(1)  The permittee must receive the approval of the city engineer and the police department therefor; 
(2)  The permittee must notify the chief of the fire district of any street so closed; 
(3)  Upon completion of construction work, the permittee shall notify the city engineer, the city police department and the fire district before traffic is moved back to its normal flow so that any necessary adjustments may be made; 
(4)  Where flagmen are deemed necessary by the city engineer, they shall be furnished by the permittee at its own expense. Through traffic shall be maintained without the aid of detours, if possible. In instances in which this would not be feasible, the city engineer will designate detours. The city shall maintain roadway services at existing streets designated as detours without expense to the permittee, but in case there are no existing streets, the permittee shall construct all detours at its expense and in conformity with the construction specifications set by the city engineer. The permittee shall be responsible for any unnecessary damage caused to any streets, sidewalks and storm sewers caused by the operation of its equipment. 
(Code 1973, § 22-23; Ord. No. 2682, § 1, 5-11-98) 
Sec. 24-23. - Manner of making excavations. 
(a)  In the making of excavations in any street, highway or public place, the excavated materials from the trenches shall be placed where they will cause the least possible inconvenience to the public. 
(b)  The width of excavation shall be no greater than is necessary for doing the work, and sheathing and bracing shall be used as necessary to keep the sides of the trench vertical and to prevent caving. 
(c)  Adequate provision for proper drainage of the areas surrounding the work shall be maintained at all times. 
(Code 1973, § 22-24) 
Sec. 24-24. - Manner of backfilling pavement. 
(a)  Excavations made in or under a street, walk or driveway pavement are to be backfilled with granular material thoroughly tamped into place and the pavement surface restored to its original condition. In such locations excavated materials are to be removed from the site of the work as the excavation is made and no such material allowed to accumulate on the site. 
(b)  Substitution may be made for granular backfill only with specific approval in writing of the city engineer in each instance. 
(c)  Approved granular backfill material shall be composed of a mixture of crushed stone or gravel and sand, free from clay lumps and trash and conforming to the following sieve analysis: 
(1) Passing 1? screen ..... 100% (2) Passing 3/4? screen ..... 35 to 65% (3) Passing #50 screen ..... Not more 
than 20% (4) Total clay and silt ..... Not more 
than 10%  
Other materials may be used only when they have the approval of the city engineer. 
(d)  Granular backfill is to be placed in horizontal layers not greater than six inches thick before compaction and shall be thoroughly compacted by mechanically operated tamping. During placement and compaction care must be taken to avoid undue segregation of coarse and fine particles. 
(e)  Each applicant for a permit shall notify the city engineer of the time and place of the backfilling of an excavation and will only make the backfill in the presence of and under the supervision of an inspector of the city. 
(f)  Every person making an excavation in or adjoining any public street, alley, public place, highway, walkway, right-of-way or easement shall restore the surface to its former condition to the satisfaction of the city engineer. 
(Code 1973, § 22-25) 
Sec. 24-25. - Manner of backfilling parkways. 
    Excavations in parkways, outside of the paved area of streets or walks, may be backfilled with earth and all grassed areas returned to their original condition. Earth backfill is to be placed and compacted in the same manner as described for granular fills or thoroughly jetted to obtain maximum settlement and shall be maintained by the person making the excavation until the area has been stabilized in the original condition. As soon as the excavation has been backfilled all excess excavated materials shall be removed from the area and disposed of. 
(Code 1973, § 22-26) 
Sec. 24-26. - City to restore streets upon excavator's failure to do so; costs. 
    Should any person making an excavation fail to restore any street, alley, public place, highway, walkway, right-of-way or easement, to standards established by the city, the city may make such restoration as deemed necessary and charge the person making the excavation one and one-half times the direct labor and materials costs of making the restoration. 
(Code 1973, § 22-27; Ord. No. 2210, § 1, 9-23-91) 
Secs. 24-27-24-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 24-46. - Required. 
    No person shall make or cause to be made any excavation in any public place, street, highway, walkway, alley, right-of-way or easement without first obtaining a permit from the city engineer. Such permit will only be granted when in the opinion of such officer the excavation requested is necessary and upon the conditions set forth in this article and such other conditions, as in the opinion of the city engineer are necessary, which shall be set forth in writing by the city engineer when the permit is issued. Each separate and distinct excavation shall require a separate permit. 
(Code 1973, § 22-15) 
Sec. 24-47. - Applicability of article to utility companies. 
    Any person owning or operating in the city facilities that are subject to the provisions of sections 24-75 et seq., shall comply therewith in lieu of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22-16; Ord. No. 16-21, § 2, 7-25-16) 
Sec. 24-48. - Application. 
    An application for an excavation permit shall be made in writing to the city engineer and shall contain a written description of the work contemplated. 
(Code 1973, § 22-17) 
Sec. 24-49. - Application fee. 
    Each application for an excavation permit required by this article shall be accompanied by a fee of $100.00 to cover the cost of the permit and the inspection of the proposed excavation by the city. Inspections required for excavations are set out by way of example and not by limitation in sections 24-21 through 24-25. In the event the holder of the permit or their agent contacts the city prior to completion of the work so as to enable the city to conduct the necessary inspections, one-half of the permit fee shall be returned to the holder of the permit. Compliance with this provision shall be evidenced by the issuance of an excavation permit refund by the city. In the event the city is not notified prior to work completion, the permit holder shall be required to reopen the excavation at their cost to enable verification by the city of the work done, and no rebate of the permit fee shall be made. 
(Code 1973, § 22-18; Ord. No. 02-60, § 1, 12-9-02; Ord. No. 04-53, § 1, 12-13-04; Ord. No. 07-12, § 1, 4-23-07) 
Sec. 24-50. - Cash bond or performance and payment bond required. 
(a)  Generally. Before any permit required by this article may be issued for work which disturbs pavement, sidewalks, curbs and/or cutters an applicant shall deposit a cash bond with the city of at least an amount equal to the cost to the city for such work as determined by the city engineer, which deposit shall remain with the city for a period or 12 months after the surface of the street, alley, public place, highway, walkway, right-of-way or easement has been restored to its former condition to the satisfaction of and verified in writing by the city engineer. In lieu of such cash deposit, any applicant may file with the city administrator a performance and payment bond, with sureties satisfactory to the city administrator, in a similar amount and for a similar time period, and holding harmless the city against all claims by others because of injuries or damages sustained as a result of any excavation made by the applicant. Any excavation not restored to the conditions required herein or in the permit being issued will be grounds for the city engineer, upon 30 days written notice addressed to the applicant at the address indicated in the application, to forfeit the bond if the excavation is not restored to the conditions contained herein and in the permit with such 30-day period. 
(b)  Replacement/new residential driveways and sprinkler systems. Subsection (a) above not withstanding, where a property owner and his agent applies for a permit required by this article in which the excavation does not disturb the street pavement, sidewalk, curb and/or cutter, then the cash escrow amount required shall be waived. 
(Code 1973, § 22-19; Ord. No. 02-60, § 2, 12-9-02; Ord. No. 03-23, § 2, 4-28-03; Ord. No. 03-33, § 2, 6-23-03) 
Sec. 24-51. - Insurance. 
    Each applicant for a permit required by this article shall, in addition to the bond requirements, furnish proof of liability insurance in the minimum amount of $300,000.00 per occurrence against all claims for damages arising from the prosecution of the work for which a permit is sought. 
(Code 1973, § 22-20) 
Sec. 24-52. - Applicant to indemnify city from suits or claims. 
    Each applicant for a permit required by this article, on condition of receiving the permit, shall indemnify and save harmless the city, its officers and employees from any suits, actions or claims of any character brought because of any injuries or damages received or sustained by any persons or property on account of the work or on account of or in consequence of any neglect in safeguarding the work. 
(Code 1973, § 22-22) 
Sec. 24-53. - Refunds not to be given nor additional permits to be issued until outstanding balances paid. 
    No cash deposit will be refunded nor any other excavation permit issued to any person, unless payment of all outstanding balances due the city for resurfacing and backfilling done by the city for such person have been paid. 
(Code 1973, § 22-28) 
Sec. 24-54. - Removal and protection of utilities. 
    The permittee shall not interfere with any existing utility without the written consent of the city engineer and the utility company or the person owning the utility. If it becomes necessary to remove an existing utility, this shall be done by its owner. No utility owned by the city shall be moved to accommodate the permittee unless the cost of such work be borne by the permittee. The cost of moving privately owned utilities shall be similarly borne by the permittee unless it makes other arrangements with the person owning the utility. The permittee shall support and protect by timbers or otherwise, all pipes, conduits, poles, wires or other apparatus which may be in any way affected by excavation work and do everything necessary to support, sustain and protect them, under, over, along or across said work. In case any of said pipes, conduits, poles, wires or apparatus shall be damaged, they shall be repaired by the agency or person owning them and the expense of such repairs shall be charged to the permittee and his or its bond shall be liable therefor. The permittee shall be responsible for any damage done any water pipes, sewer, gas pipe, electric conduit or other utility and its bond shall be liable therefor. The permittee shall inform itself as to the existence and location of all underground utilities and protect the same against damage. 
(Ord. No. 2682, § 2, 5-11-98) 
Sec. 24-55. - Protection of adjoining property. 
    The permittee shall at all times and at his or its expense preserve and protect from injury any adjoining property by providing proper foundations and taking other measures suitable for the purpose. Where in the protection of such property it is necessary to enter upon private property for the purposes of taking appropriate protective measures, the permittee shall obtain a license from the owner for such purpose. Whenever it may be necessary for the permittee to trench through any lawn area, the sod shall be replaced after the excavation has been backfilled. All construction and maintenance work shall be done in a manner calculated to leave the lawn area clean of earth and debris and in a condition as nearly as possible to that which existed before such work began. The permittee shall not remove even temporarily any trees or shrubs which exist in parking strip areas or easements across private property without first having notified and obtained the consent of the property owner, or in the case of public property, the appropriate city department or city official having control of such property. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not be applicable to any excavation work under the supervision of city authorities by employees of the city or by any contractor of the city performing work for and in behalf of the city necessitating openings or excavations in streets. 
(Ord. No. 2682, § 2, 5-11-98) 
Sec. 24-56. - Liability of the city. 
    The ordinance from which sections 24-54 through 24-56 derive shall not be construed as imposing upon the city or any official or employee any liability or responsibility for damage to any person injured by the performance of any work for which a permit is issued hereunder, nor shall the city or any official or employee thereof be deemed to have assumed any such liability or responsibility by reason of inspections authorized hereunder, the issuance of any permit or the approval of any excavation work. 
(Ord. No. 2682, § 2, 5-11-98) 
Sec. 24-57. - Landscape sprinkler and irrigation systems. 
(a)  No person shall construct or install a landscape sprinkler or other irrigation system in the public right-of-way without having obtained an excavation permit. 
(b)  An excavation permit for a landscape sprinkler or irrigation system being completely or partially within a public right-of-way shall only be issued if the request, therefore, is accompanied by plans, drawing or specifications for said landscape sprinkler or irrigation system which comply with the following: 
(1)  No sprinkler head, similar discharge fixture, or piping may be located within 24 inches of any roadway, driveway, sidewalk, other pavement, utility junction box, transformer, street light or other permanent structure. 
(2)  All landscape sprinkler and irrigation system pipe installations within a roadway right-of-way, except vertical connections to sprinkler heads or other discharge fixtures, must be buried a minimum of 18 inches below grade. 
(c)  The owner of property which is served by a landscape sprinkler or irrigation system installed within a roadway right-of-way is responsible for the relocation and/or removal of such system if it is obstructing public works or utility companies working within the public right-of-way. 
(d)  The owner of property which is served by a landscape sprinkler or irrigation system installed within a right-of-way is responsible for any damage caused by the installation, use of or the result of the presence of that system. 
(Ord. No. 03-05, § 2, 1-27-03) 
Secs. 24-58-24-70. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - RIGHTS-OF-WAY USAGE CODE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Note- See editor's note for Ch. 7.5, Art. IV. 

Sec. 24-75. - Title, definitions and word usage. 
(a)  Title. This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Rights-of-way usage code". 
(b)  Definitions and word usage-General. For the purposes of this Code, the following terms, phrases, words and abbreviations shall have the meanings given herein, unless otherwise expressly stated. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future tense and vice versa, words in the plural number include the singular number and vice versa and the masculine gender includes the feminine gender and vice versa. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and "may" is permissive. For convenience, the first letter of terms, phrases, words and abbreviations defined in this Code have been capitalized, but an inadvertent failure to capitalize such letter shall not affect meaning. 
(c)  Definitions. As used in this article, the following terms shall have these prescribed meanings: 
    Antenna. Facilities consisting of any device, array or antenna of any kind, including, but not limited to, a whip antenna, panel antenna or satellite antenna, that transmits or receives electromagnetic signals to deliver microwave, cellular, broadcast or other non-wire voice, data or video communications service through the airwaves above the rights-of-way and which attach to either pre-existing or subsequently approved facilities. 
    Antenna fee. A compensation fee approved by the board of aldermen established in section 7.5-39 as amended from time to time for the rent of a portion of the rights-of-way by a person having facilities within the rights-of-way. The antenna fee shall be calculated on the number of antennas located within the ROW and shall not include any linear foot fee, but a ROW user may be subject to both an antenna fee and a linear foot fee. 
    Applicant. The person applying for and receiving a ROW permit for ROW work. 
    Application. That form which an applicant must use to obtain a ROW permit to conduct ROW work. 
    City. The City of Ballwin, Missouri, and its agencies, departments, agents and employees acting within their respective areas of authority. 
    City administrator. The city administrator of the City of Ballwin, Missouri. 
    Board of aldermen or council. The governing body of the city. 
    City facilities. Any facilities, street light poles, lighting fixtures or other structures or equipment located within the rights-of-way and owned by the city. 
    Director. The city's public works director or such other person designated by the city administrator to administer and enforce this Code. 
    Emergency rights-of-way (or ROW) work. Includes, but is not limited to, ROW work made necessary by exigent circumstances to repair, control, stabilize, rectify or correct the following: 
(1)  An unexpected or unplanned outage, cut, rupture, leak or any other failure of facilities that prevents or significantly jeopardizes the ability of a ROW user to provide service to customers;
