ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 25-1-25-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SUBDIVISION PLATS 

Sec. 25-26. - Plat submission required. 
    Every subdivision of land within the city shall be shown upon a preliminary plat and submitted to the planning and zoning commission for its recommendation no later than the close of business on the Friday preceding the Monday six weeks before the regularly scheduled meeting of the zoning commission. All preliminary plats, accompanied by the recommendation of the planning and zoning commission, shall be submitted to the board of aldermen for its consideration and approval or disapproval. 
(Code 1973, § 23-17; Ord. No. 2366, § 1, 3-14-94; Ord. No. 99-38, § 1, 8-23-99) 
Sec. 25-27. - Provisions of article not applicable in certain instances. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the sale or exchange of small parcels of land to or between adjoining property owners, when the sale or exchange does not create additional lots. All provisions of the applicable zoning must be met and a plat of the revised parcels shall be recorded with the county recorder of deeds. 
    The city planner or other city employee appointed by the city administrator shall determine whether a proposed boundary adjustment is within the purview of this section 25-27. If such boundary adjustment qualifies in accordance with this section, then the city planner or other city employee is authorized to approve such boundary adjustment on behalf of the city so as to enable the property owner or owners to record the revised parcels with the St. Louis County Recorder of Deeds. 
(Code 1973, § 23-18; Ord. No. 00-19, § 1, 3-27-00) 
Sec. 25-28. - Prerequisites to plat approval-Sidewalks. 
    No plat of any proposed subdivision submitted to the board of aldermen shall be approved unless the subdivider shall have previously installed, or shall have included and provided, adequate security, as provided by section 25-32 or 25-33, for the ultimate installation of concrete sidewalks as required in accordance with section 24-4, pertaining to streets and sidewalks, on both sides of all streets, as well as completely surround all cul-de-sacs. 
(Code 1973, § 23-19) 
Sec. 25-29. - Same-Streetlights. 
    No plat of any proposed subdivision submitted to the board of aldermen shall be approved unless the subdivider shall have previously installed, or shall have included and provided, adequate security, as provided by section 25-32 or 25-33, for the installation of streetlights, rated at a minimum of 175 watts and 6,800 lumens of output, or equal, mounted on a post a minimum of three inches in diameter and a minimum of 16 feet in height at intervals of not more than 250 lineal feet upon each street or roadway. 
Sec. 25-29.5. - Provisions for sidewalks and streetlights not applicable in certain instances. 
(a)  Plats of any proposed subdivision submitted to the board of aldermen having three or fewer lots are exempt from the requirements of installing streetlights or sidewalks under the following conditions: 
(1)  When the lots adjacent to the lots proposed to be subdivided do not have existing streetlights or sidewalks; and 
(2)  When the proposed lots abut a private street, road or throughway and are not proposed to be accepted by the city as a public street, road or throughway. 
(b)  When the proposed lots are contained in a subdivision plat or site plan approved by the board of aldermen as part of a development in an R-4 planned multiple dwelling district, C-1 commercial district, C-3 planned limited commercial district, mixed use development district (MXD), or community unit plan, streetlights or sidewalks shall be provided as required by the approved plat or site plan. 
(c)  The security required under section 25-32 or 25-33 shall include an amount sufficient, in addition to other amounts, to pay for the underground installation of and one year's operation or rental of such streetlights or the installation of sidewalks as may be required under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 23-20) 
Sec. 25-30. - Deed restrictions; contents of preliminary plats. 
(a)  Every preliminary plat submitted to the board of aldermen shall be accompanied by copies of any deed restrictions which are too lengthy to be shown on the plat. 
(b)  Preliminary plats submitted to the zoning commission and the board of aldermen shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The boundary lines of the area being subdivided with accurate distances and bearings; also all sections and U.S. survey lines and the boundary lines of sewer, school and other legally established districts within or adjoining the subdivided area. 
(2)  The lines of all proposed streets and alleys with their widths and names and the lines of all sidewalks. 
(3)  The location of all proposed street lighting fixtures. 
(4)  Existing sanitary and storm sewers, water mains, culverts and other underground structures within the tract or immediately adjacent thereto. The location and size of the nearest water main and sewer or outlet are to be indicated in a general way on the plat. 
(5)  The accurate hachured delineation of any property which is offered for dedication for public use. 
(6)  The lines of all adjoining lands and the lines of adjacent streets and alleys with their names and widths. 
(7)  All lot lines and an identification system for all lots and blocks. 
(8)  Building lines and easements for rights-of-way provided for public use, services or utilities with figures showing their dimensions. 
(9)  Name of subdivision and description of property subdivided, showing its location and extent, points of compass, scale of plan and name of owner or subdivider. 
(10)  All stormwater information as required and outlined in section 25-72. 
(11)  The size of all proposed lots in square feet. 
(Code 1973, § 23-21) 
Sec. 25-31. - Record plat. 
(a)  Upon approval of the preliminary plat by the board of aldermen, the petitioner has 120 days to submit the record plat to the city planner. The planner shall verify that the record plat is consistent with the preliminary plat and shall arrange for the signature of the mayor and the city clerk. 
(b)  Every record plat submitted for final review shall be submitted on mylar and shall contain the following: 
(1)  All information required on the preliminary plat. 
(2)  The line of departure of one street from another. 
(3)  All dimensions, both linear and angular, necessary for locating boundaries of subdivisions, lots, streets, alleys, easements and building lines, and any other areas for public or private use. The linear dimensions shall be expressed in feet and decimals of a foot. 
(4)  Radii arcs and chords, points of tangency, central angles for all curvilinear streets and radii for all rounded corners. 
(5)  All survey monuments and benchmarks together with their descriptions. 
(6)  Certification by a reputable civil engineer or surveyor to the effect that the plan represents a survey made by him and that the necessary survey monuments are correctly shown thereon. 
(7)  Private restrictions and trusteeships and their periods of existence. Should such restrictions and trusteeships be of such length as to make lettering of the same on plat impracticable and thus necessitate the preparation of a separate document, reference to such instrument shall be made on the plat. The plat shall contain proper acknowledgment of owners and consent of the mortgagee to such plat and restrictions. 
(8)  The intended location of all concrete monuments necessary to establish the subdivision boundaries and all rights-of-way. 
(Code 1973, § 23-22) 
Sec. 25-32. - Guaranteeing completion of subdivision improvements-Surety bond. 
    No plat or development plan of any proposed subdivision submitted to the board of aldermen shall be approved, nor shall any grading or construction of any kind associated with such subdivision begin, or a subdivision permit be issued unless the subdivider has filed with the city clerk one surety bond to secure to the city the actual construction of all subdivision improvements including grading in a manner satisfactory to the board of aldermen, and within a period specified by the board, which period shall not exceed two years. 
(Code 1973, § 23-23; Ord. No. 99-47, § 1, 9-27-99) 
Sec. 25-33. - Same-Cash deposit agreement; release of money. 
(a)  In lieu of the requirements of section 25-32 for the filing of a bond, the person submitting a plat to the board of aldermen may submit cash in the amount of 110 percent of the sum estimated by the city engineer for completion of the subdivision improvements in accordance with the city's standards and specifications at the time the improvements are to be accepted by the city. 
(b)  Upon depositing the cash with the city, the person submitting the cash shall sign an agreement with the city guaranteeing that the improvements set forth in the plat shall be completed within two years of approval of the subdivision plat in conformance with the city's specifications and standards at the time the improvements are to be accepted by the city. 
(c)  The agreement shall allow the person making a cash deposit to request disbursements in the amount of 95 percent of the labor and material used in the construction and installation of the improvements. The city will make such disbursements within 30 days of the request, provided that the city engineer has certified the construction and installation of the improvements in accordance with city specifications and standards and approval of the costs. If the city engineer does not make such certification within 30 days following receipt of the request for disbursements, then, at the request of the person making the cash deposit, a registered professional engineer selected by the city shall make an inspection and issue a report certifying the completion and value of the work or noting any deficiencies and the cost of correcting the deficiencies. The city shall make disbursements for the net amount of the request after deducting the costs for correcting deficiencies. The fees and expenses of the certified engineer shall be paid by the person responsible for making the subdivision improvements. In no event will more than 95 percent of the money deposited be disbursed until the final inspection and acceptance of the improvements is made by the city and approved by the board of aldermen. In no event shall the payment of a progress payment be construed as final acceptance of the subdivision improvements. 
(d)  If the subdivision improvements are not completed within two years of the approval of the subdivision plat, or if construction or installation of the improvements is stopped for 120 days or more, the city may declare the money held as a deposit forfeit to the city as liquidated damages and not as a penalty. 
(Code 1973, § 23-24; Ord. No. 00-15, § 1, 3-13-00) 
Sec. 25-34. - Submission fee. 
    Each plat for the subdivision of any tract of land within the city and each plat for the resubdivision of any tract of land previously subdivided which shall be submitted to the board of aldermen shall not be considered or approved by the board of aldermen unless the person applying for the same and submitting the plan to the board of aldermen shall pay to the city clerk the sum of $250.00 per lot of the subdivision, or $1,500.00, whichever amount is the greatest. 
(Code 1973, § 23-25; Ord. No. 2658, § 1, 12-8-97; Ord. No. 04-03, § 3, 1-26-04) 
Sec. 25-35. - Inspection fees. 
    In addition to other applicable fees and permits required to for site improvements made in the city, the following inspection fees associated with the corresponding time required for inspections under the Code shall apply as indicated: 
Site inspection component Fee Streets (including under drains, curb and gutter, paving) $0.50 per linear ft. of curb and gutter Sidewalks $0.25 per linear ft. of sidewalk Sewers $0.30 per linear ft. of pipe Landscaping $12.00 per dwelling unit Retaining walls less than four feet in height $100.00 per retaining wall  
(Ord. No. 06-11, § 1, 2-13-06) 
Sec. 25-36. - Lot platting. 
    Whenever a new residential subdivision is platted with fee simple lots adjacent and contiguous to an existing residential development, the lots in the new subdivision shall be arranged, laid out or platted in a manner that the side yard of any new lot abutting and contiguous to the rear yard of an existing approved, platted and recorded lot in an adjacent contiguous subdivision, shall have a side yard setback of not less than 15 feet regardless of a permitted smaller minimum side yard setback requirement of the zoning district in which the new lot is located. 
(Ord. No. 10-35, § 1, 10-25-10) 
Sec. 25-37. - Subdivision acceptance. 
    Subdivision acceptance shall be based on the following criteria: 
(a)  Design. 
1.  Centerline radii shall generally be a minimum of 125 feet. 
2.  Profile grade shall not exceed six percent without approval of the Board of Aldermen. 
(b)  Construction. All construction shall conform to the current editions, as written, of the St. Louis County Standard Specifications for Highway Construction and the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District's Standard Construction Specifications for Sewers and Drainage Facilities, except as hereby modified: 
1.  Meramec River gravel shall be used in all concrete pavement, curbs and gutters, and sidewalks. 
2.  All joints in pavement or curbs and gutters shall be saw cut to a depth of one-third the thickness of the concrete at 15-foot intervals. No tooled joints are allowed. 
3.  The pavement surface course shall not be placed until all other construction activity is completed unless authorized by the city engineer. 
4.  The developer shall be responsible for any and all damage or deterioration to site improvements until accepted by the city for public maintenance. 
5.  All trenches and excavations within the public right-of-way and beneath all paved areas shall be granular backfilled. 
6.  All off-site restoration shall be done with like materials. In all cases, turf shall be replaced with matching sod, but no sod shall be placed between April 1 and October 1 without written approval of the city engineer. Seeding with annual grasses or other temporary ground covering vegetation is required during this period. Restoration, including repair or replacement of improvements or landscaping shall be completed within 30 calendar days of initial disruption. The city engineer or city planner may issue time extensions. vegetation must be in place for at least 90 days and living before acceptance. 
(c)  Process for partial escrow releases. 
1.  The developer must request all escrow releases in writing. 
2.  The city engineer or his designee will verify the accuracy of the request. 
3.  Upon verification of accuracy, the city engineer may approve the release up to 95 percent of the escrowed amount for each particular item. 
4.  The city engineer will submit the escrow release to the city administrator for authorization of this release. 
5.  The fully approved and authorized release of cash escrows will be submitted to the finance officer for release. The fully approved and authorized release of letter of credits will be submitted to the issuing bank. Surety bonds cannot be partially reduced. 
(d)  Acceptance. 
1.  Upon request of the developer or upon expiration of the subdivision permit, the city engineer or his designee will inspect the subdivision improvement and prepare a list of corrections, repairs, or uncompleted items. 
2.  The developer will be required to complete all items identified on this "punch" list. The city will not accept any cracked concrete curb and gutter, sidewalk or pavement sections or asphalt that is rutted, sunk, humped, or cracked. The damaged sections shall be replaced or repaired in a manner acceptable to the city engineer. 
3.  All grading and restoration shall have been completed in accordance with the approved plans or any approved amendments to those plans. 
4.  The developer shall furnish the city engineer a copy of MSD's letter accepting the storm and sanitary sewers for MSD's maintenance. 
5.  The developer shall furnish a certification from a professional engineer licensed in the State of Missouri that the stormwater detention basin and water quality facility have been constructed in accordance with the approved plans and it has the required capacity. 
6.  The developer shall furnish the city a copy of the "As Built" drawings. 
7.  Upon receipt of the "As Built" drawings, MSD acceptance for maintenance letter, the detention basin and water quality facility certification and completion of all "punch" list items, the board of aldermen will consider a request to accept the streets and sidewalks for city maintenance provided they are within properly dedicated public rights-of-way and easements. 
8.  The board of aldermen reserves the right to accept any part(s) of the public improvements at any time, regardless of the status of completion of the remaining subdivision improvements and escrow releases. 
(e)  Final release of remaining escrow. All remaining escrows will be released upon completion of all improvements and the items identified in the "punch" list as may be requested by the board of aldermen and upon passage of the acceptance ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 11-46, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 25-38. - Lot split procedure. 
(a)  No lot split shall be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds unless and until approved by the planning and zoning commission in compliance with this section. 
(b)  Whenever there is a tract or previously subdivided parcel under single ownership which is to be re-subdivided into two lots, and which exists as a legal lot of record, such a division shall be designated as a "lot split" if the following criteria are met: 
(1)  That no additional improvements are required that would necessitate the posting of an escrow or bond, including concrete sidewalks, water mains, and landscaping within a street right-of-way dedication. Establishment of a right-of-way only shall not be construed as an improvement in this section. 
(2)  That no provisions for common land or recreational facilities are included in the proposal. 
(3)  That the use of the lot split procedure does not adversely affect the subject parcel or any adjoining properties. 
(4)  That the proposed lot split is not in conflict with any provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
(5)  No variances are required. 
(c)  The procedure for approval of a lot split shall be as follows: 
(1)  Two drawings of a certified survey, prepared by a land surveyor registered in the State of Missouri on paper that is either eight and one-half inches by 11 inches or 11 inches by 17 inches in size showing the following shall be submitted: 
a.  A legal description of both the original lot and each of the proposed lots. This must be surveyed and performed by a registered surveyor. 
b.  North arrow and graphic scale. 
c.  Location of proposed and existing streets and adjoining property. 
d.  Location of all existing buildings. 
e.  Within their boundaries approval of the St. Louis County Water Company and the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District shown on the tract drawings. 
6.  Name, address, and telephone number of the owner of record and a copy of the deed of record. 
(2)  The following items shall accompany the required survey: 
a.  Filing fee of $750.00. 
b.  Certificate from the office of the St. Louis County collector of revenue showing that there are no delinquent taxes outstanding. 
c.  Verification of fire hydrants and adequacy of water supply from applicable fire protection district. 
d.  Verification of proper placement of survey monuments from the city engineer, or an escrow agreement or land subdivision bond to guarantee installation of survey monuments in accord with subsection 25-31(b)(6) of article. 
(3)  The planning and zoning commission shall conduct a public hearing and review the proposed lot split to ensure compliance with all design and improvement requirements of this ordinance and the zoning ordinance. Lot splits found to be in compliance with the above requirements shall be approved by the planning and zoning commission and shall be recorded with the recorder of deeds of St. Louis County. The lot split plat shall be tendered to the St. Louis County Recorder of Deeds after adoption by the board of aldermen of an ordinance approving same. 
(Ord. No. 17-25, § 1, 10-9-17) 
Secs. 25-39-25-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 25-51-25-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STORM SEWERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Flood hazard areas, ch. 10; sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 21. 

Sec. 25-71. - Required. 
    Plats of subdivisions proposed within the limits of the city shall not be approved unless provision is made in such plats for adequate storm sewers, depending upon the topography and the general makeup of such subdivision. 
(Code 1973, § 23-46) 
Sec. 25-72. - Construction not allowed in subdivisions without adequate storm sewers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct any structure in any subdivision, a plat of which is approved after June 10, 1957, unless the subdivision contains storm sewers which meet the requirements of Chapter 11, Article III of the Ballwin Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1973, § 23-47; Ord. No. 11-21, § 1, 6-13-11) 
Sec. 25-73. - Approval. 
    The city engineer and the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District (MSD) shall approve in writing the layout of storm sewers as set out in plats of subdivisions submitted to the city for approval. 
(Code 1973, § 23-48) 
Sec. 25-74. - Stormwater standards and criteria. 
(a)  Improvement plans. The improvement plans required under section 25-30 shall be prepared in accordance with and so as to reflect the stormwater standards and criteria set forth in this section, as well as any other standards and criteria of MSD. 
(b)  Drainage. All construction, details and specifications pertaining to sanitary and stormwater drainage shall be in accordance with the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District requirements unless otherwise noted herein. A professional engineer's seal is required on all plans submitted for approval. 
(c)  Design criteria. All stormwater design is to be by the rational method, except that in certain large developments, the use of other methods of analysis such as the unit hydrograph will be considered for stormwater design. However, prior approval must be obtained from the director of public works at the preliminary design state, where use of the unit hydrograph or other methods of analysis is requested. Runoff factors based on a 25-year design frequency are generally as follows:

From U.S. Weather Bureau Technical Paper No. 40, Rainfall Frequency Atlas of the United States, for durations from 30 minutes to 24 hours and return periods from one to 100 years. 
(d)  Drainage structures. 
(1)  All structures shall be designed for HS20-44 loading. 
a.  Bridges. 
1. Bridges in floodplain areas shall be designed for 100-year storm frequency and provide one foot of freeboard from bottom of superstructure to high water elevation. 
2. Bridges in nonfloodplain areas shall be designed on a storm frequency of 100 years and provide two feet of freeboard between the bottom of superstructure and high water elevations. 
b.  Culverts. 
1. Crossroad culverts, not at low points, shall be designed on a storm frequency of 25 years, with entrance control and two feet of freeboard at the shoulder line. 
2. Culverts, at or near low points in floodplains, shall be designed on a storm frequency of 100 years with entrance control and two feet of freeboard at the shoulder line. 
3. Culverts, at or near low points not in floodplains, shall be designed on a storm frequency of 50 years, with entrance control and two feet of freeboard at the shoulder line. (Refer to Bureau of Public Roads Hydraulic Engineering Circular No. 5 entitled Hydraulic Charts for the Selection of Highway Culverts.) 
4. All crossroad culverts shall be R.C.P. or poured-in-place reinforced concrete. Driveway culverts may be C.M.P. with the approval of the city engineer. 
c.  Roadways. Whenever a watercourse is proposed or exists within proximity of or approximately parallel to an existing or proposed roadway, the low shoulder elevation of the roadway shall be established from the highwater elevation with one foot of freeboard in nonfloodplain areas and two feet of freeboard in floodplain areas. 
d.  Street inlets. In certain cases, where steep grades or other unusual conditions are encountered, a grated trough may be required in lieu of multiple inlet structures upstream in order to eliminate excessive bypass. 
e.  Pipes. 
1. All pipes shall be reinforced concrete except for underground detention facilities. Alternate materials for underground detention facilities having an expected life comparable to concrete pipe may be substituted. Show type and specification of all pipes (e.g.,ASTM,C76,class III). 
2. Pipes normally should be sized using the partial full flow design; however, under special circumstances approved by the city engineer and MSD, full flow design will be allowed, provided hydraulic grade line information is shown indicating adequate freeboard. 
3. For 36-inch-diameter pipes or smaller, a minimum one-percent grade or three feet per second velocity will be required. For pipes larger than 36-inch diameter, the minimum grade is the grade that will establish a self-cleaning velocity of three feet per second. 
(e)  Watercourses. Where a subdivision is transversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided utility easements and drainage easements and access easements of sufficient width and slope to permit access and maintenance if future expansion can reasonably be anticipated, and these easements shall conform substantially with the lines of such watercourses or drainage rights-of-way. The channel capacity shall be improved for and from a 25-year frequency storm in a manner approved by the city engineer. No structure shall be constructed closer than 20 feet to the easement of any creek, stream or other major watercourse. 
(f)  Erosion control. Erosion control for drainage systems within or directly related to the right-of-way will be required in swales, ditches or creeks at inlet structures and at the discharge points of all pipes where the velocity exceeds four feet per second. Silting basins or diversion channels will be required during the construction period to insure that mud and other debris are not washed into natural watercourses, new or previously constructed storm sewers, or onto new or existing streets (public or private). 
(g)  Stormwater retention. Where required by the board of aldermen, stormwater shall be retained onsite and metered out at specific rates to prevent possible flooding and erosion downstream. Detention shall be provided to retain the 25-year pre- and post-development differential runoff. The difference between the 25-year post-development and the 15-year undeveloped runoffs shall be detained. Stormwater and Detention Design Criteria and Guidelines, St. Louis County, as modified by the city and on file with the city engineer, shall dictate the design of all detention/retention basins. The simplified volume formula or an alternative acceptable to the city engineer shall be used. 
    In addition to any other criteria as may be imposed, the city engineer shall direct that: 
(1)  All storm water detention basins with a depth, from the low water flow line to the overflow structure flow line, of four feet or more shall be fully enclosed by a fence, dividing wall or similar structure offering security from access if the side walls have a slope greater than 3:1. 
(2)  All basin enclosing structures must be at least four feet tall when measured on the side facing away from the detention area, and must have a lockable gate large enough to provide access for maintenance equipment. 
(3)  All enclosures must be placed at or above the overflow elevation of the basin. 
(4)  Any basin that is not required to have an enclosure must have side slopes no steeper than 6:1. 
(5)  All basins must be final graded and sodded to a level two feet above the overflow elevation immediately upon the completion of the storm water pipe installation. An extension to this provision may be granted in writing by the city engineer due to weather or other mitigating conditions for a period of not more than 180 days. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(7)  All enclosing structures must be compatible in design and style with the surrounding neighborhood and may contain no openings large enough to allow the passage of a six-inch diameter sphere. 
(h)  Plans and calculations. Plans shall be any scale from one inch equals ten feet through one inch equals 100 feet, so long as the scale is an increment of ten feet. Plans shall be prepared on exhibits 24 inches by 36 inches. All calculations submitted shall be prepared in a legible manner. Plans and calculations shall include the following information: 
(1)  Site drainage map. A drainage map is required and should be developed from a base reproduction of the site plan or grading plan. The map must include the following information: 
a.  The existing and proposed contours at one- or two-foot intervals, for the subject property, extending offsite as required for proper design of proposed improvements. Contour intervals other than the above as determined by the topography must be approved by the city engineer or city planner. Use U.S.G.S. datum only. Locations and elevations of benchmark references are available from the county department of highways and traffic and the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District. 
b.  The location of existing and proposed property lines, streets, sinkholes, area within the tract subject to inundation by stormwater, railroads, easements of record, and other significant natural features such as wooded areas and rock formations, etc. 
c.  All existing and proposed stormwater facilities, such as inlets, manholes, pipes, culverts, bridges, channels, etc. 
d.  All existing and proposed improvements where required for proper design review, which may include, but not be limited to, pavement, curbs, sidewalks, buildings, utilities, etc. 
e.  The existing waterways, including names; if no name, an indication of creek or river to which the waterways are tributary. 
f.  The runoff details are required, showing flows tributary to each proposed and existing structure and cumulative flows in pipes and gutters. Include "Q" and area. 
g.  All existing bodies of water (such as lakes or ponds) indicating surface area and elevation. 
(2)  Supplemental drainage map. A supplemental map may be required and should be developed from a portion of U.S.G.S. quadrangle map. Map must include the following information: 
a.  The site boundary. 
b.  The watershed tributary to the project area. 
(i)  Surface drainage. For areas not in floodplain. The following shall be included and/or observed: 
(1)  No sheet flow will normally be allowed over retaining walls or terraces that are steeper than a 3:1 slope and/or greater than five feet in height. Berms and/or swales shall be provided to collect the flow at the top of the terrace and carry it to a drainage structure. Total accumulation inside berms and/or swales shall be a maximum of four cubic feet per second. 
(2)  Provide critical cross sections, profiles, and hydraulic computations for ditches and swales with flows in excess of one c.f.s. and creeks with flows in excess of four c.f.s. 
(j)  Drainage structures. The lateral location of all drainage structures shall be shown by street centerline stationing and perpendicular offset distance, in addition to the following requirements: 
(1)  Inlets shall be appropriately sized and spaced, taking into consideration bypass, depth of flow and width of spread of flow in gutters. Width of spread shall not exceed six feet. 
(2)  For inlets in vertical sag curves, the center of the main chambers shall be placed within one foot of the exact mathematical low point. 
(3)  All manholes shall be located outside of proposed roadway pavements. 
(4)  Inlets shall be located as follows: 
a.  Inlet face one foot from back of roadway curbing along driving lanes. 
b.  Inlet face flush with back of roadway curbing along parking shoulders. 
c.  Area inlets in roadway ditches to be compatible with ultimate improvements. 
d.  Inlets shall be placed at intersections such that no part of the inlet structure or sump is in the curb rounding. 
(5)  Bypass shall be minimized at inlet structures and shall be shown on the hydraulic computations and site drainage map. 
(6)  Where termination of pavement occurs, erosion protection in the form of asphalt curb, gutters, additional structures, paving and/or revetment may be required. 
(7)  Data required on plans and/or profiles shall include: 
a.  Type of structure (single, double, grated, etc.). 
b.  Flowline and top elevations. 
c.  "Q" in upstream gutter line and within pipe reach. 
d.  The hydraulic grade line at the structure shall be shown on the plan, profile and computation sheets. 
e.  Hydraulic computations shall be included as part of the site improvement plans. 
(8)  For nonstandard structures two additional sets of plans shall be submitted for review. 
(k)  Pipes. 
(1)  The following information shall be shown on the plans and/or profiles: 
a.  Location of pipes and length. 
b.  Grade. 
c.  Alignment. 
d.  Curve data for radius pipes. 
e.  Material and class. 
f.  Limits of granular backfill. 
(2)  At intake structures, such as flared end section or headwalls, entrance control shall be applied. Two-foot minimum freeboard is required. Check for inundation upstream. Cutoff walls are required to be three feet deep on headwalls. Concrete headwalls are required at the end of the flared end section and at the joint between the pipe and flared end section. 
(3)  Outfall termination shall conform to the following: 
a.  All concrete outfall pipes shall have a reinforced concrete headwall or a flared end section with cutoff wall and revetment or paving. 
b.  Any corrugated metal outfall pipe shall be installed with a cutoff wall. Revetment or paving may be required for erosion control. 
c.  If discharge is at a property line, an attempt will be made to acquire a discharge easement on the adjacent property, prior to approval. A guarantee will be required for future extension of the outfall to the property line. 
(4)  Open trenching of roadway pavements will be permitted only with the prior approval of the city engineer. 
(5)  Road closings will not be permitted without prior approval of the board of aldermen. Contractors will be required to maintain one lane open to traffic at all times. 
(l)  Sanitary sewers. All construction details and specifications shall be in accordance with the applicable requirements for drainage structures and pipes within the road rights-of-way and other MSD requirements. 
(m)  Bridges and culverts. The following shall be included and/or observed: 
(1)  Submit two additional sets of plans for bridges and poured-in-place concrete culverts. 
(2)  Structure widths shall be designed for the ultimate roadway width. Guardrail and fencing shall be required at appropriate locations. 
(3)  Reinforced concrete approach slabs will be required for all bridges. 
(4)  The following information shall be shown for all culverts: 
a.  Size, type, grade, alignment, minimum cover for the loading, wing-walls, and/or erosion protection in the form of paving or revetment or floodwall, if required, cutoff footings, etc. 
b.  Any connections to culverts shall be shown with a detail; no utilities to run through any culvert. Alignment and changes of grades shall be, as previously mentioned, for pipes. Slopes from culverts to roadways shall not be steeper than 3:1 and shall be sodded or protected with paving or revetment where required. 
(n)  Roadway dams. The following shall be included and/or observed: 
(1)  A soil engineering design report shall be submitted indicating the adequacy of the proposed dam construction. 
(2)  Any dam design shall be supported by a soils report prepared by a professional engineer registered in the state. In no case shall side slopes be steeper than 3:1. 
(3)  Adequate top width for pavement and sidewalks shall be provided on dams where the roadway fill serves as the dam. In such cases, the dam shall be designed to store a 100-year 20-minute storm with one foot of freeboard, assuming a blocked overflow structure exists. Berms, guardrail, fence, etc., may also be required. 
(4)  The relief line from the spillway structure or the overflow structure in the dam shall be sized on the total upstream tributary area, using the ultimate runoff factor. 
(5)  An adequate overflow structure shall be provided which will be of reinforced concrete construction, with the openings covered by grates. Such system shall be designed to maintain the required freeboard and storage and shall also be equipped with a drain valve so that the water level may be lowered for maintenance purposes. 
(6)  Erosion protection will be required where the stability of the structure may be endangered. 
(7)  The dam design and soils report may require review by the Corps of Engineers or other agencies designated by the city engineer. 
(o)  Sinkholes. The following shall be included and/or observed: 
(1)  An engineering report shall be submitted indicating the existing sinkhole conditions, intended use and proposed treatment to be accomplished as a part of the development. 
(2)  A sinkhole can be used as a point of drainage, provided that an adequately sized outfall pipe is provided to an existing natural discharge point such as a ditch, creek, river, etc., in case the sinkhole becomes inadequate to discharge at the required rate. 
(3)  Where required sinkholes within a development shall be treated by approved methods. 
(p)  Floodplain study. In order to develop or improve any land subject to flooding and inundation during a 100-year storm (floodplain area), or any land adjacent to a ditch, creek or other drainageway, a property owner or user shall submit a floodplain study to the board of aldermen, MSD, the U.S. Corps of Engineers, state department of natural resources and FEMA, which plan shall show the provisions for adequate flood protection against high water. 
(1)  The floodplain study must be prepared by a registered professional engineer of demonstrated competence in hydrology and must show the protection against high water for the proposed improvements, the effect of proposed improvements on other properties, and such other hydrologic problems as may result from the improvements. 
(2)  Roadway shoulders and low window or doorsill openings of proposed buildings shall be set two feet above the determined high-water elevation. 
(3)  The following information is to be included in the floodplain study: 
a.  Profile of creek or ditch. 
b.  Profile of top of bank. 
c.  Cross sections of critical points on the stream. 
d.  U.S.G.S. map of watershed. 
e.  Computations establishing the "Q" and the high water elevations for use in determining low sill elevations, etc. 
(4)  The above hydraulic computation shall include the average mean velocities. Where velocities in improved channels exceed five feet per second, erosion protection must be provided. 
(5)  Where any portion of the floodplain is filled, a volume equal to the filled volume must be excavated to provide for equivalent storage in the floodplain area. 
(6)  Two copies of the floodplain study shall be submitted for review. 
(q)  Creeks. All creeks within the property being developed within 100 feet of a lot line shall be improved to handle a 25-year storm, and such channel shall be protected from erosion by a means acceptable to the city engineer. The existing 500 feet of downstream channel shall be analyzed as to capacity after development. At the discretion of the board of aldermen, a cash payment to the city in the amount of 110 percent of the estimated cost may be made in lieu of such improvements. 
(Code 1973, § 23-50; Ord. No. 2393, § I, 7-11-94; Ord. No. 2493, § 1, 12-11-95; Ord. No. 2575, §§ 1, 2, 2-24-97; Ord. No. 02-32, § 1, 6-24-02) 
Sec. 25-75. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates the provisions of this division shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and be subject to a fine as provided in section 1-6. Any person who constructs or begins to construct any structure in any subdivision which does not contain storm sewers as required by this division shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this division. 
(b)  Any permit for construction or any approval of a plat made in violation of this division shall be null and void. 
(Code 1973, § 23-49) 
Secs. 25-76-25-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STREETS; MONUMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 24. 

Sec. 25-91. - Street construction. 
(a)  All subdivisions that shall be platted in the city and approved by the board of aldermen shall contain streets constructed in accordance with the typical section illustrations of section 24-6 entitled "illustrations." 
(b)  All asphalt streets shall be constructed with a concrete curb and gutter on a crushed limestone base course having a total width of two feet six inches. 
(c)  All streets shall have underdrains beneath the curb and gutters along both sides of the pavement, or as directed by the city engineer. 
(d)  Concrete curbs and gutters shall have sawed transverse joints at a maximum spacing of 12 feet. All joints shall be sealed with a rubberized filler. 
(Code 1973, § 23-56; Ord. No. 2584, § 3, 3-24-97) 
Editor's note- Specific requirements for street and sidewalk construction are available from the city engineer. See also section 24-4, which specifies mix composition and requirements for expansion joints. 
Sec. 25-92. - Grade of streets. 
    All streets and roadways in any subdivision that shall be layed out or established within the confines of the city shall be platted and made according to an engineer's grade survey. Street longitudinal grades greater than six percent must be approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1973, § 23-57) 
Sec. 25-93. - Width of streets. 
(a)  All streets and roadways shown on any subdivision plat hereafter approved by the board of aldermen shall have a pavement width of not less than 26 feet and shall be located in the center of a right-of-way having a minimum width of 50 feet dedicated to the city. Under no circumstances shall any land in the dedicated right-of-way be used in determining the size of any lot within the subdivision. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to construct any street or roadway in any subdivision in the city that is not in accordance with the approved plat and minimum street construction standards of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 23-58; Ord. No. 2056, § 1(23-58), 1-22-90) 
Sec. 25-94. - City engineer to inspect and approve streets. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer to inspect all streets constructed under the provisions of this division and it shall be necessary that he give written notification to the city administrator of the approval of streets so constructed when they have been constructed in compliance with this division. If bond has been given for the construction of streets as provided in this division, the obligation of the sureties and principal under the bond shall not be released without the written approval of the city engineer, and if streets are constructed prior to plat approval, approval shall not be given without such written notification. 
(Code 1973, § 23-59) 
Sec. 25-95. - Fees for inspections. 
    The city engineer shall receive a fee of $20.00 per day for making street inspections, and such fee shall be paid by the person who requests plat approval and street inspection. 
(Code 1973, § 23-60) 
Sec. 25-96. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25-97. - Plats and construction of buildings not to be approved if streets not minimum width. 
    The city engineer, board of aldermen or any other official or officials of the city or their deputies or agents shall not approve the plat of any subdivision unless the streets provided for therein comply with the provisions of this chapter. Any approval or any permit for the construction of any building in any subdivision which does not contain streets complying with the provisions of this chapter for which a subdivision plat was approved shall be void. 
(Code 1973, § 23-62) 
Sec. 25-98. - Rental of equipment and services. 
    The city may contract with the trustees of a private subdivision to rent equipment owned by the city and the services of employees of the city to private subdivisions located in the city for use under the direction of city employees. 
(Code 1973, § 23-63) 
Sec. 25-99. - Contracting of rentals; hours and fees. 
    The rentals provided for in section 25-98 shall be by contract, and the city engineer is authorized to execute such contracts on behalf of the city, subject to resolutions of the board of aldermen setting the prices for such use and the hours of such use. 
(Code 1973, § 23-64) 
Sec. 25-100. - Use of rental equipment and services of city does not constitute upkeep by city. 
    The use of the equipment and the services of employees of the city as provided in section 25-98 shall not constitute the repair, maintenance or improvement of streets in the private subdivisions by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 23-65) 
Sec. 25-101. - Conformity with master plan and official map. 
    Any proposed subdivision or development shall conform to the master plan and official map of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 23-66) 
Sec. 25-102. - Street relationship. 
(a)  Conformity. The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the official map and master plan and shall be considered in their relationship to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in their relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. Where not shown on an official map or master plan, the arrangement and other design standards of streets shall conform to the provisions found in this division. 
(b)  Relation to adjoining street system. The arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall make provisions for the continuation of the existing streets in adjoining areas. 
(c)  Projection of streets. Where adjoining areas are not subdivided, the arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall make provision for the proper projection of streets. 
(d)  Streets to be carried to property lines. When a new subdivision or similar development joins unsubdivided land susceptible to being subdivided, then the new streets shall be carried to the boundary of the tract proposed to be subdivided. A temporary cul-de-sac shall be constructed where new streets terminate. Where such street extensions are too short to be of value prior to the subdivision of the adjoining property, or where no room exists for the construction of a temporary cul-de-sac, the construction of the street extension and associated sidewalks may be omitted at the discretion of the board of aldermen, providing the adequate right-of-way is dedicated for the eventual construction of the street. In this situation, the developer shall pay the equivalent dollar value of such roadway and sidewalk construction to the city to be held for the eventual construction of the improvements. 
(e)  Cul-de-sacs generally. Cul-de-sacs shall be constructed at all street termini. 
(Code 1973, § 23-67) 
Sec. 25-103. - Placement of monuments. 
    After completion of all site improvements, the subdivision boundary and street right-of-way shall be established with concrete monuments of the standard type and size. Those monuments shall be set by a land surveyor registered in the state, utilizing established standard practices. 
Secs. 25-104-25-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OPEN SPACE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 18. 

Sec. 25-121. - Provided. 
(a)  All subdividers or developers of residential property shall provide for reasonable and adequate amounts of open space parks and recreational facilities within their developments. This requirement shall be deemed satisfied by the use of any one of the following alternatives, or a combination of them: 
(1)  Dedication of open space land for public use; 
(2)  Fees in lieu of dedication; or 
(3)  Development of parks and recreational facilities within the subdivision or development. 
The methods selected shall be done in accordance with the requirements of the city planner and shall be reviewed by the zoning commission and the board of aldermen prior to acceptance of the subdivision plat; but in any event acceptance or rejection shall be by ordinance. 
(b)  This provision applies to development of all residential lands in the city, including all subdivisions, lots, tracts and parcels of land. 
(c)  Neighborhood facilities, open space parks and recreational facilities that are developed consistent with the requirements of this article shall be within or near the development area, so that the intention of these requirements, specifically, to serve the needs created by such development is accomplished. 
(d)  No building permits shall be issued until provisions of this article are satisfied. 
(Code 1973, § 23-70; Ord. No. 2293, § 1, 2-8-93) 
Sec. 25-122. - Dedication of open space lands. 
(a)  Schedule. If the dedication of open space land is selected as the compliance of a particular developer with the requirements of this article, dedication shall be by deed or plat and shall be as provided in the following schedule of dedication: 
SCHEDULE OF DEDICATION 
(Minimum Requirement) 
Zoning Amount of 
Dedication 
(percent) R-1A .....  2  R-1 .....  5  R-2 and R-3 .....  9  R-4 and R-5 ..... 12  MXD/PSD ..... 10.5  
The above required open space shall be in addition to minimum required yard areas and space reserved for offstreet parking in the applicable zoning ordinance. The percentage figures of dedicated space shall be computed on gross area of the development or subdivision. 
(b)  Suitability. While specific requirements may vary, all lands to be dedicated shall meet the following general requirements: 
(1)  Size and shape shall normally contain not less than two contiguous acres. 
(2)  Location and accessibility shall be located in or adjacent to the subdivision or area to be served and easily accessible to same. Consideration should be given to placing park areas where they can be added to by future subdivisions, or the addition of open space required by this provision to an existing park. 
(3)  Fifty percent of the land dedicated shall have a grade of less than six percent; it is permissible for the remainder of the dedicated property to be covered with steep slopes, streams, ditches, lakes or other natural features. 
(4)  The land dedicated or to be dedicated should be conveyed in its natural state. Removal of trees, topsoil and other natural features shall be prohibited unless there is previously acquired the written approval from the city administrator. 
(5)  The park board shall review the suitability of the land to be dedicated and provide a written recommendation to the board of aldermen. 
(6)  The board of aldermen shall have the final determination as to the suitability of dedicated lands under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 23-71) 
Cross reference- Zoning, app. A. 
Sec. 25-123. - Credit for private parks and recreational facilities. 
    Any subdivision plat containing suitable facilities to be reserved, constructed and maintained by a private organization to serve the needs of the subdivision being created may satisfy the requirements of this article, provided: 
(1)  They fulfill the area and suitability requirements of this article; and 
(2)  They are reviewed by the planning and zoning commission and the board of aldermen, and are approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1973, § 23-72) 
Sec. 25-124. - Fee in lieu of land dedication. 
(a)  Authorized. When a subdivision is not able to dedicate land as required by section 25-122, or when otherwise approved or required by the board of aldermen, a fee in lieu of dedication shall be paid to the city. The amount of the fee shall be the lesser of the following two formulas: 
(1)  An amount determined by multiplying the percentage of dedication of land from the schedule contained in section 25-122(a) times the actual verified cost of the land (without improvements) being subdivided, provided that the land has been acquired within the past 12 months. Where the land has not been acquired within the last 12 months, a current fair market value for the computed equivalent amount of land shall be determined by negotiations with the city or via independent professional appraisal to be prepared at the developer's cost. 
(2)  An amount determined by adding together the recreation operation contribution and the recreation development contribution which are computed as follows: 
Recreation operation contribution. The current fiscal year's recreation department operating budget, divided by the total number of dwelling units in the city, multiplied by the number of dwelling units or lots (whichever is the larger number) approved for the development. 
Recreation development contribution. The National Recreation and Park Association standard for the number of acres of park land per person, multiplied by the number of dwelling units or lots (whichever is the larger number) approved for the development, multiplied by the average number of persons per household in the city as measured in the most recent Department of Commerce decennial census, multiplied by an average cost per acre of vacant land in the Ballwin area of $150,000.00. 
(b)  Time of payment of fee. The fee in lieu of dedication shall be paid at the time of final plat presentation unless expressed written approval from the city is given as to the terms of any other arrangement. No grading or construction of any kind will be allowed until the fee is paid. 
(c)  Special fund created for fee. All fee-in-lieu-of-dedication payments shall be maintained in a special park account established by the city, and such funds may be used only for the purchase and development of park and recreational facilities. 
(d)  The fee authorized by this section shall be paid by each lot in the subdivision except that a lot that contains an existing single family dwelling that will be continued to be used for residential occupancy shall not be liable for the fee. 
(Code 1973, § 23-73; Ord. No. 2637, § 1, 9-22-97; Ord. No. 05-35, § 1, 8-8-05; Ord. No. 15-20, § 1, 3-23-15) 
Sec. 25-125. - Resubdividing. 
    Any lands resubdivided shall be subject to the provisions of this article, except that any lands previously dedicated or fees in lieu of dedication previously paid will be credited against the requirements mandated by this provision. In no instance, however, will land so previously dedicated or fees previously received by the city be returned or refunded to the developers or subdividers. 
(Code 1973, § 23-74) 
Sec. 25-126. - Natural features. 
    Natural features such as trees, brooks, hilltops and views shall be preserved wherever possible. The subdivider shall designate or show at the time of filing of his final plat what trees and other natural features are to be retained. Artificial and natural lakes and wooded areas are to be preserved and encouraged as much as possible. 
(Code 1973, § 23-76) 
Chapter 26 - SWIMMING POOLS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-1.5 et seq.; buildings and structures, ch. 7; health and sanitation, ch. 12; housing, ch. 13; bathing and swimming in parks, § 18-29; sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 21; zoning, app. A; use regulations in public activity districts, app. A, art. VIIIA, § 2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Swimming pool regulations. 
    Any drainage, overflow, leakage, splash out or other discharge of water from a public, semipublic or family swimming pool shall be collected and diverted to a public storm water system through a pipe, hose or similar conveyance. No such discharge shall be allowed to enter any surface drainage way that is located upon or flows through any parcel of land that is not the property upon which the swimming pool is located. Under no circumstances shall any discharge be allowed in a manner that causes standing or stagnant water or creates a nuisance for the owners or tenants of surrounding properties. 
(Ord. No. 02-26, § 1, 5-21-02) 
Secs. 26-2-26-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC AND SEMIPUBLIC POOLS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-26. - Regulations of county health commissioner to be effective; scope of regulations. 
(a)  The rules and regulations promulgated by the county health commissioner shall become effective upon approval by the board of aldermen and shall be filed with the city clerk as a public record. The rules and regulations may provide: 
(1)  The minimum sanitary requirements for the design, equipment, maintenance and operation of swimming pools and bathing places. 
(2)  The qualification of any lifeguard or attendant at any swimming pool or bathing place. 
(3)  The minimum safety facilities and apparatus to be installed and maintained at any swimming pool or bathing place. 
(4)  A maximum bathing load of any swimming pool or bathing place. 
(5)  The minimum sanitary standards of operation for any wading pool or spray pool. 
(6)  The data to be submitted with any application for construction, alteration, extension or modification of swimming pools or bathing places and to provide the manner and terms upon which such approval shall be granted or modified. 
(b)  Any rule or regulation shall meet the minimum standards of the state department of health, but nothing herein shall prevent the county health commissioner from requiring compliance with higher requirements where such higher requirements are essential to maintain a sanitary condition. 
(Code 1973, § 24-17) 
Sec. 26-27. - Amendment of rules and regulations. 
    Any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this article may be amended or repealed. 
(Code 1973, § 24-18) 
Sec. 26-28. - Approval of plans and specifications required. 
    No swimming pool or bathing place shall be constructed, altered, extended or modified unless the plans, specifications and any additional information relating to such swimming pool or bathing place, as requested by the health official, are submitted to the health official and after review by the health official, are found to comply with the minimum sanitary requirements as required by this article and unless written approval for the construction, alteration, extension or modification of the swimming pool or bathing place is issued by the health official. The review of the plans by the health official shall relate only to insuring adequate protection to the public health. 
(Code 1973, § 24-19) 
Sec. 26-29. - Work to conform to building and plumbing codes. 
    Any swimming pool or bathing place, approved by the health official, shall be constructed, altered, extended or modified in accordance with the provisions of the building code and plumbing code. 
(Code 1973, § 24-20) 
Sec. 26-30. - Compliance with sanitary standards required. 
    Every swimming pool or bathing place shall have such equipment and shall be so operated as to comply with the minimum sanitary requirements as are provided for in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 24-21) 
Sec. 26-31. - Records to be submitted. 
    Any person owning or operating a swimming pool or bathing place under this article shall submit such operational and analytical records as may be requested by the health official to determine the sanitary conditions of the swimming pool or bathing place. 
(Code 1973, § 24-22) 
Sec. 26-32. - Periodic inspections, weekly water analysis. 
    The health official shall make such inspections as may be necessary of any swimming pool or bathing place that may be open for public use and may collect and analyze samples to determine that the water shall be of satisfactory bacterial, chemical and physical quality, at least once each week or as frequently as may be necessary, to insure compliance with the minimum sanitary requirements of this article and any rule or regulation promulgated as provided hereunder. 
(Code 1973, § 24-23) 
Secs. 26-33-26-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 26-51. - Required to operate swimming pool or bathing place. 
    Every person owning, operating or maintaining a swimming pool or bathing place under this article is required to hold an unrevoked permit from the county health department. 
(Code 1973, § 24-29) 
Sec. 26-52. - Permit and current certification to be displayed. 
    The permit required by section 26-51 shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in full view of any patron, together with the current certification of the health official as to the satisfactory sanitary condition of the swimming pool or bathing place. 
(Code 1973, § 24-30) 
Secs. 26-53-26-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FAMILY SWIMMING POOLS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 26-71-26-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 26-91. - Required for construction or alteration of pools. 
    No person, whether as owner, contractor, employee or agent, shall construct, alter, improve, remodel, remove or demolish; nor authorize, commence or assist in the construction, alteration, improvement, remodeling, removal or demolition of a family pool unless there has previously been filed with the building commissioner an application in writing for a building or demolition permit, and such permit has been issued, for a family pool. 
(Code 1973, § 24-52) 
Sec. 26-92. - Application. 
    An application for a building permit under this article shall be submitted, in such form as the building commissioner may prescribe, by the owner or lessee, or agent of either; or the architect, engineer or builder employed in connection with the proposed work. Each application shall contain: 
(1)  The full names and addresses of the applicant and of the owner. 
(2)  The principal officers if the owner is a corporate body. 
(3)  A brief description of the proposed work. 
(4)  Such additional information as may be required by the building commissioner for a proper understanding of the proposed work. 
(Code 1973, § 24-53) 
Sec. 26-93. - Plans and specifications to accompany application. 
    Each application for a permit under this article shall be accompanied by four sets of the following, one of which must be black and white: 
(1)  Pool plans. 
(2)  Pool specifications. 
(3)  Plot plan or diagram in form and size suitable for filing permanently with the permit record, drawn to scale with all dimensions figured showing accurately the size and exact location of all proposed new construction. 
(Code 1973, § 24-54) 
Sec. 26-94. - Information to be shown by plans and specifications. 
(a)  Plans, specifications and pertinent explanatory data required to be submitted in connection with an application for a permit to construct a swimming pool under this article or any alteration, addition, remodeling or other improvement to a swimming pool shall comply with the following requirements and shall include the following plans and information as well as such other data as may be reasonably requested by the health department: 
(1)  Plans shall be drawn to scale indicating all dimensions, including the length, width and depth of the pool and the width of the pool deck. 
(2)  A profile plan showing the same information shall also be required. 
(3)  A cross section shall be included of scum gutters and/or skimmers. 
(4)  Pipe diagrams showing the size of all pipes, inlets, outlets, makeup water lines, vacuum lines, waste and discharge lines, circulation and other piping. 
(5)  The pool equipment room layout showing filters and their location, pumps, chlorinators, chemical feeders, flowmeter gauges, sight glass, strainers, hair and lint interceptors, dimensions of filter room and its location, floor drain, sumps and other pertinent information. 
(6)  The liquid capacity of the pool. 
(7)  The liquid capacity of any wading pool. 
(8)  The kind, number and size of filters, including the square footage of the filter area in each unit. 
(9)  The top capacity in gallons per minute. 
(10)  A description of chemical feeders for soda ash and alum. 
(11)  The type, kind and description of chlorinator. 
(12)  A description of the gauges and water flowmeter. 
(13)  A description of the skimmers and scum gutters. 
(14)  The type and range of testing equipment, including chlorine. 
(15)  Pool pump capacity and pressure or head at filter and backwash flow. 
(b)  Plans for in-ground pools must be approved by and bear the seal of a registered architect or of a registered mechanical or civil engineer. 
(Code 1973, § 24-55) 
Sec. 26-95. - Commissioner to approve or disapprove application. 
    If, after examining an application for the construction, alteration, improvement, remodeling, removal or demolition of a family pool, the building commissioner finds the same to be in compliance with the law and ordinances applicable thereto and that the proposed construction or work will be safe and meet the requirements of all applicable ordinances, he shall approve such application and issue a permit for the proposed work as soon as practicable. If his examination reveals otherwise he shall reject such application, note his findings in a report to be attached to the application and deliver the same to the applicant. 
(Code 1973, § 24-56) 
Sec. 26-96. - Work to conform to approved plans. 
    All work performed under a permit issued by the building commissioner under this article shall conform to the approved application and plans and approved amendments thereof. It shall be unlawful to reduce or increase the area or the construction or work provided for in an application hereunder. 
(Code 1973, § 24-57) 
Sec. 26-97. - Revocation of permit for making false statements in application. 
    The building commissioner may revoke a permit or approval issued under the provisions of this article if he finds that there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to a material fact in the application or plans on which the permit or approval was based. 
(Code 1973, § 24-58) 
Sec. 26-98. - Permits for work in connection with pool construction not to be issued until plans approved. 
    No permit for building, plumbing, electrical or other work in connection with the construction, alteration, improvement or remodeling of a family pool shall be issued until the plans and specifications for such pool, the application for such permit and pertinent explanatory data shall have been submitted to and approved by the health department. 
(Code 1973, § 24-59) 
Cross reference- Buildings and structures, ch. 7. 
Sec. 26-99. - Pool not to be used until certified. 
    No family pool shall be used in whole or in part until a certificate of swimming pool use shall have been issued by the building commissioner certifying that such pool conforms to the provisions of this article and has been constructed in accordance with the application and the permit therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-60) 
Sec. 26-100. - Acceptance of incomplete plans not to constitute waiver of requirements. 
    The acceptance of any plans not showing all the requirements for the granting of a permit shall not be construed as constituting a waiver of any provision of this article or of sanctioning any violation hereof. 
(Code 1973, § 24-61) 
Secs. 26-101-26-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MINIMUM DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 

Sec. 26-116. - Conformance with standards required. 
    No family pool shall be constructed, improved, remodeled or altered and no permit for such construction, improvement, remodeling or alteration shall be issued unless the minimum design and construction requirements as set out in this division are observed in connection with such construction, improvement, remodeling or alteration. 
(Code 1973, § 24-66) 
Sec. 26-117. - Required inspections, fees. 
(a)  The following types of inspection are required and shall be made by the building commissioner of family pools, being constructed, altered, remodeled or improved within the city: 
(1)  Preliminary. 
(2)  Rough. 
(3)  Final. 
(b)  Fees for inspections shall be the same as those outlined in the building code (chapter 7). 
(Code 1973, § 24-67) 
Sec. 26-118. - Commissioner may order discontinuance of work; notice. 
(a)  Whenever the building commissioner finds that construction or work in connection with the erection, construction, alteration or repair of a swimming pool, which is regulated, permitted or forbidden by this article, is being done or conducted in violation of the requirements of this article or in violation of a detailed statement or plans submitted and approved hereunder, or of a permit or certificate issued hereunder, he shall have authority to issue a written notice or order upon the person responsible therefor directing discontinuance of such illegal action and the remedying of the condition which constitutes a violation of the provisions or requirements of this article. 
(b)  Whenever the building commissioner finds by reason of defective or illegal work in violation of a provision or requirement of this article, that the continuation of construction or work is contrary to public health, safety or welfare, he shall have authority to order, either orally or in writing, all further work to be stopped and may require suspension of work until the condition and violation has been remedied. 
(Code 1973, § 24-68) 
Sec. 26-119. - Plumbing to be done by licensed plumber. 
    Plumbing work on a family pool and pool equipment shall be done by a qualified licensed journeyman plumber. 
(Code 1973, § 24-69) 
Sec. 26-120. - Electrical installations. 
    All electrical installations under this article shall meet the requirements of the National Electrical Code and must be done by an electrician licensed by the county. 
(Code 1973, § 24-70) 
Sec. 26-121. - Pools to be flow-through recirculating type. 
    All family swimming pools shall be of the flow- through recirculating type. 
(Code 1973, § 24-71) 
Sec. 26-122. - Pools to be leakproof. 
    All family swimming pools shall be so constructed as to provide a tight, leakproof tank with easily cleaned surfaces and designed to withstand the expected forces to which it will be subjected. 
(Code 1973, § 24-72) 
Sec. 26-123. - Grading. 
    Grading in and about a family pool area shall be such as shall in the judgment of the building commissioner avert surface water entering such pool. 
(Code 1973, § 24-73) 
Cross reference- Grading, mining, filling and clearing, ch. 11. 
Sec. 26-124. - Wall slope. 
    The wall slope shall not be more than two feet horizontal in five feet vertical to a depth up to five feet from top. 
(Code 1973, § 24-74) 
Sec. 26-125. - Inner surfaces to be rounded. 
    The inner surface of a family pool must be coved, rounded or bullnosed at all joints, corners, angles of bases, walls, floors or curbs. No sharp corners or projections will be permitted. 
(Code 1973, § 24-75) 
Sec. 26-126. - Stairways and ladders. 
    Steps and stairways for entering or leaving the pool should be of such construction as to minimize danger. Convex, semicircular or triangular steps shall have rounded corners. Ladders or stairways shall be located at the deep end, if there is only one. Treads or ladders or steps shall be constructed of nonrotting material, shall be slip-resistant and shall be devoid of recesses which may support vegetable or animal life. 
(Code 1973, § 24-76) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, ch. 5; weeds and vegetation, ch. 29. 
Sec. 26-127. - Runways. 
    Runways at least four feet wide shall be placed adjacent to a family pool, sloped one-fourth inch to the foot away from such pool, and should be of material approved by the building commissioner, which shall be of nonslip texture and easily cleaned. 
(Code 1973, § 24-77) 
Sec. 26-128. - Underwater lights. 
    Lights under water shall be of the wet niche type, shall be equipped with a grounded deck junction box and shall carry the approval of the Underwriters' Laboratory, Inc. 
(Code 1973, § 24-78) 
Sec. 26-129. - Walkways recommended. 
    A walkway is recommended from the dwelling or accessory building when long areas of open ground or lawn must be traversed by bathers before reaching a family pool area. This is to prevent contamination on the feet. 
(Code 1973, § 24-79) 
Sec. 26-130. - Pool heaters. 
(a)  When used, family pool heaters must be approved by the building commissioner and be of a type with a minimum of 10,000 Btu input per hour, or 94,000 Btu per hour for liquid propane gas. They may be powered by natural or artificial gas or a combination of bottled gas or oil and may be direct or indirect heaters. 
(b)  Family pool heaters shall include and be equipped with the following: 
(1)  A thermostat. 
(2)  An automatic safety pilot to prevent the burner from turning on unless the pilot is lit. 
(3)  A pressure regulator to insure constant pressure. 
(4)  A water pressure safety switch to prevent main burners from coming on unless water is flowing under satisfactory pressure. 
(5)  A high limit safety switch to shut off the heater if water gets too hot. 
(6)  A pressure relief valve to relieve any excessive pressure within the tank. 
(c)  Direct injection of steam into a family pool for the purpose of heating the water shall not be allowed. 
(d)  Heating coils in a family pool shall not be allowed. 
(Code 1973, § 24-80) 
Sec. 26-131. - Color of inside surfaces. 
    All family pools shall be white or of a light color on the inside surface. 
(Code 1973, § 24-81) 
Sec. 26-132. - Diving area. 
    The minimum depths and area for diving shall be as follows: 
Deck
